El Yunque.name: El Yunque National Forest
El Yunque.description: Plan a day trip to the only tropical rainforest in the U.S. National Forest System. With 29,000 acres of lush foliage and 25 miles of year-round trails, this is a nature enthusiast’s sanctuary. Attempt to spot elusive wildlife like the Puerto Rican parrot on a rejuvenating hike, soar through the canopies on a zipline, or go horseback riding at Carabalí Rainforest Park. If time permits, visit the Yokahú Observation Tower which has an elevation of 1,575 feet and provides expansive views of the mountains. Sporadic showers are common here—check their website for the latest information about trail statuses and park closures before setting out.
El Yunque.review_summary: It was a quick trip via tour guide, but overall great.  Their visitor's center is quite excellent and is worth the initial stop as an introduction to so many of the unique parts of the rain forest.  We didn't get a lot of hiking time for our trip, but we did get to see some of the highlights off of the main road.  It's definitely worth visiting if on the island.

location_id.name: Monte Guilarte State Forest
location_id.description: Features many hiking trails, a lookout point, campgrounds, and cabins for rent. Home of one of the island's tallest peaks.
location_id.review_summary: I hiked to the top of Mt. Guilarte Feb. 20, 2020.   I am a healthy 60 year old, the hike took about 50 min.  The view from the top was worth the trip.  The path was well worn, but there was some scrambling and climing involved near the top.  I had hiking shoes, think hiking boots and gloves would be a good idea. There weren't too many markings but the path was well used, it would be hard to miss the trail.  There was absolutely no litter along the trail and greenery and occasional birds were pleasant to see, bring a camera.

Villa Sotomayor, Adjuntas, Puerto Rico.description: Parador Villas Sotomayor, the first and the only eco-tourist complex in the mountains of Puerto Rico. Here you can reduce the stress, make your life last longer, and strength your family ties. Our green areas, trees, flowers and open space, makes this a very special place to enjoy and relax with your family and friends. We do our best to make you feel comfortable, just like in home.
Villa Sotomayor, Adjuntas, Puerto Rico.review_summary: I went on Feb 2024 as a family trip. The facilities are in horrible conditions. The rooms are not clean, the bathroom are nasty , there’s no proper cleaning nor lighting in the rooms. The closet doors are broken and also the windows. The curtains for privacy is peeling off, the setting of the room make it difficult to walk. You cant walk at night, there’s no lights. I have to use my cell phone flashlight to see, that is dangerous and scary. Also not safe. They have a deck in the back where the hammocks are and the wood is rotting away, you don’t even dare to step on it. Not enough staff. Frankly is horrible!

Aguada Museum and Historic Railway Stati.name: Aguada
Aguada Museum and Historic Railway Stati.review_summary: Honestly some of the best food we’ve ever had! This place was recommended when we were visiting Rincon a year ago, then we went back to PR recently and hit Mimosa twice, we love it so much. I highly recommend the huevos rancheros with short rib, which is about the best thing I’ve ever eaten, and the benedict on their amazing homemade bread. Their juices are also out of this world good! And their prices are incredibly reasonable, I’d be there every day if I lived close by!

Church of San Francisco de Asís, Aguada,.name: Parroquia San Francisco de Asis
Church of San Francisco de Asís, Aguada,.review_summary: The parish church of San Francisco de Asis in Old San Juan is a beautiful old church.  In need of a few repairs, but very nice.  We stopped in twice for daily Mass during our recent trip to San Juan.  Nice service, nice priest celebrated the Mass, love to see the Franciscan friar habits… very cool.  Very interesting confessional, just an office chair on wheels, which is chained to the wall!  :-)  For those interested, Mass is celebrated in Spanish, and, as of the date of this review, daily Mass (M-F) is at 12:15pm, and Sunday Masses are at 7:00am, 9:00am and 11:00am.  It was a beautiful service… recommend to stop by for Mass or just to see the church!

Pico Piedra Beach, Aguada, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This beach is clean, have bathrooms, showers and 3 restaurants  -mexican, seafood, criollo- inside the area and another one next to it. It has plenty of parking space and the area is safe. Very nice place to spend the day with family and friends. I gave it 4 stars only because there are other beaches with clearer water.

Aguadilla Pueblo and its plazas, Aguadil.name: Aguadilla
Aguadilla Pueblo and its plazas, Aguadil.review_summary: Lots going on here. Loud music, food/drink vendors, restaurant/bar, facilities, water as calm as can be…perfect for swimming: no waves for kiddies or beginners, tons of distance for more active folks. No strong currents that I experienced. Snorkeling is good along the pier/jetty and people jumping off them into the water. I saw giant bait ball right there where you least expect near swimmers and tropical fish snacking on algae on the underwater structures. Beautiful sunset with people in the water into the night. Strong late afternoon sun, no shade along the southern side where the roped off area for swimming. Parking limited, back fill along the road.

Crash Boat Beach, Aguadilla, Puerto Rico.name: Playa Crash Boat
Crash Boat Beach, Aguadilla, Puerto Rico.description: Jump off the pier into the turquoise waters at Playa Crash Boat—the calm waters are home to an array of marine life, perfect for snorkeling and diving. Hop on a banana boat for a thrilling ride around the beach, then hit the food trucks around the pier for a pina colada and casual Puerto Rican fare. Later in the day, walk to the lookout to watch the sunset. You'll find picnic tables but no showers or toilet facilities. Both paid and free parking is limited, so be sure to arrive early. Or consider visiting along a tour of west Puerto Rico. – Tripadvisor

location_id.name: Punta Borinquen Lighthouse
location_id.review_summary:
The Aguada lighthouse, also known as "Faro de Punta Borinquen," is located in Aguada, Puerto Rico.
It was built in 1889 and has been guiding ships along the northwest coast of Puerto Rico for over a century.
The lighthouse is situated on a hill overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, providing stunning views of the coastline and surrounding area.
The structure is made of iron and stands 110 feet tall, making it one of the tallest lighthouses in Puerto Rico.
The lighthouse was automated in 1963, and it is still in operation today, serving as an active aid to navigation.
It is a popular tourist attraction, drawing visitors who are interested in its historical significance and picturesque location.
The lighthouse is part of the Punta Borinquen Light Station, which includes several other buildings and structures.
The surrounding area offers opportunities for outdoor activities such as hiking, picnicking, and enjoying the coastal scenery.
The lighthouse has been designated as a historic site and is maintained by the Puerto Rico Conservation Trust.
Visiting the Aguada lighthouse provides a unique opportunity to appreciate both its architectural beauty and its role in maritime history.

location_id.name: Parque de Bombas
location_id.description: This loudly-colored building in black, red, green and yellow, was built for a volunteer fire-fighter's brigade. (Temporary Closed)
location_id.review_summary: While visiting the main plaza in Ponce we visited this restored old fire hall, now a small museum. We were offered a free tour by a personable young guide. We learned lots about the building and city's history in an entertaining 20 minutes. Free clean bathroom was a bonus!

location_id.name: Castillo De San Cristobal
location_id.description: This massive, 27-acre historic fort protecting the eastern gate of old San Juan is considered the largest Spanish fort built in the Americas.
location_id.review_summary: Castillo de San Cristobal is a nice stop in Old San Juan if you have enough time. But most visitors are short on time and in my opinion, it would be better to focus on Castillo San Felipe del Morro which is larger and has much better views of the ocean as well. For people into History, there is a lot of information about the history of Puerto Rico. The Wikipedia page speaks of antique gun shooting which would have been fascinating to watch but we were not there on a 3rd sunday

Añasco Pueblo and its main plaza, Añasco.review_summary: Great experience! Super fun with the perfect amount of challenge and silliness. Super helpful staff. Would do it again for sure!

Tres Hermanos Beach, Añasco, Puerto Rico.review_summary: The main parking lot is closed and very few people are using this beach, but we were able to park near the police station and take a short walk down to the beach. We met Pedro who has a little area set up for his use with decorations that he has found in the ocean and his row boat. He was so kind to show us the fish that he caught and to help us harvest 4 fresh coconuts with the sweetest coconut water. They went from tree to tummy in less than 10 minutes. A+++ experience. The water is very calm here making it ideal for young children.

Historic Arecibo Pueblo, Arecibo, Puerto.review_summary: On our way to Rincon on a Monday night and stopped in off a whim. Great flank steak and some of the best rice and beans I’ve ever had. I am rarely impressed enough to write a review. This place deserves a stop.

Cathedral of San Felipe Apóstol, Arecibo.name: Catedral San Felipe Apostol
Cathedral of San Felipe Apóstol, Arecibo.description: The Cathedral of St. Philip the Apostle is an antique catholic cathedral located in the town of Arecibo. It was built mid 17th century and was damaged by earthquakes on three different occasions. The structure that stands today as the cathedral was completed on 1846. It features neoclassic ornamentation and renaissance-style windows.The beautiful cathedral is the second largest church in Puerto Rico.
Cathedral of San Felipe Apóstol, Arecibo.review_summary:
The Cathedral of Saint Philip the Apostle was built beginning in the late 18th century. The first church, built in the middle of the 17th century, was destroyed by an earthquake in 1787. Construction of its replacement began soon after, although it was not completed until 1846. Four days after its dedication, an earthquake seriously damaged it. Repairs were not completed until 1882. The 1918 earthquake damaged the vault so badly that it was replaced by a flat concrete roof; a vaulted ceiling of composition board was placed inside.
The cathedral of Arecibo is Puerto Rico's second-largest church after the Cathedral of San Juan. The plan is rectangular with three naves; the side naves are cut short to allow large flanking chapels, which occupy almost half the length of the church. The apse is semicircular, and has an unusual half-dome covering it. The facade is a triangular composition of three stages. The top stage, a short central tower, is a later addition, according to local architects and historians. Neoclassic ornamentation is used in an academic fashion on the lowest stage, but the other two show a less traditional use of bands and pilasters. The Renaissance-style windows are uncommon in Puerto Rican churches, but the central tower over the entrance is a common motif used throughout the island.

Cueva Ventana, Arecibo, Puerto Rico.name: Cueva Ventana
Cueva Ventana, Arecibo, Puerto Rico.description: Cueva Ventana offers an unforgettable journey into nature and history. Nestled atop a limestone cliff, this eco-touristic gem features guided tours showcasing stunning views, fascinating petroglyphs, and diverse wildlife like bats and frogs. Learn about Puerto Rico’s ecology and culture with our knowledgeable guides. Perfect for adventurers, families, and nature lovers, Cueva Ventana promises a safe, educational, and breathtaking experience.
Cueva Ventana, Arecibo, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We took the UTV ride up, it was amazing.  Our guide Jesus, was excellent.  The tour was fun & educational.  Reminds us of natures beauty.   The views are spectacular- worth the trip.

location_id.name: Lake Dos Bocas
location_id.description: Lake Dos Bocas is an artificial lake that was created on 1942 as a hydroelectric power plant and works as a water reserve. The lake features a creative culinary experience. It is located between the towns of Arecibo and Utuado. It also has five restaurants that you are taken to by boat. You can board the boat from a dock called El Embarcadero that departs every hour and makes stops at all of the restaurants. The boat ride takes about 30 minutes where you can enjoy nature, the beautiful lake and think about the delicious food you could indulge.
location_id.review_summary: Beautiful and relaxing weekend away from the city and popular tourist areas. Rented a kayak from Hacienda Las Cascadas and stayed in La Finca Regina Airbnb.

El Indio Cave and petroglyphs, Arecibo,.name: Cueva Del Indio
El Indio Cave and petroglyphs, Arecibo,.description: An important site within indigenous Taíno culture, Cueva del Indio is home to a beautiful selection of prehistoric cave art on Puerto Rico’s Atlantic coast. Admire over 80 pre-Columbian indigenous petroglyphs made on the cave’s limestone walls between 1200 and 1500 A.D., and learn more about the island’s indigenous cultures. The scenic hike to the cave also boasts pretty coastal views and impressive grassy cliffs. You might want to join a tour that departs from San Juan—it's a great way combine your visit to the cave with other attractions in the area, such as the Cueva Ventana and the Arecibo Observatory. – Tripadvisor
El Indio Cave and petroglyphs, Arecibo,.review_summary:
A nice stop along the northern shore.  I read the conflicting reviews about parking.  All beaches in PR are free, and you can find a place to park.  If you do decide to park for free, do it on the east side of the arch (before you get to the paid lot).  That said, we paid to park and it gives you a good spot to start (and there are porta potties).   

We went to the cave and then the arch.  My family is adventurous and I would not recommend going into the cave.  Once you get to the bottom, which is about 20 feet down, it's a small space and there isn't much to see or explore. 5 minutes down there and you are ready to go out.  However, there is the problem.  The entry hole is small and "one-way", so if a tour group is behind you then you could be stuck down there for a while. This happened to us.   The tour guides were very rude.  They would not the 2 of us get out before they got their people through the opening.  That said, there is a trick to getting out if you have the ability to climb.  If you at the bottom and are facing the carvings on the wall, turn to your right and there is a pocket that you can enter and climb up and out. My son is 12 and was the one to figure it out.  It's was fairly easy to do but do so at your own risk.  We saw another couple later in the day and they said they were stuck down there for about 40 minutes, as they were not comfortable with the climb.  Also as you walk around up top, there are about 5 holes that are the size of a manhole cover.  If you fall through it's not going to end well.  Do not walk and take pictures at the same time.  Pay attention.

We then worked east toward the beach/arch.  It is a easy, short hike that leads to some very nice views.

Overall a nice spot - but think twice about the cave if it is crowded.

Poza del Obispo Beach, Arecibo, Puerto R.name: La Poza Del Obizpo
Poza del Obispo Beach, Arecibo, Puerto R.review_summary:
Beautiful Beach,
Protected by rocks and a coral reef; water splashes over the rocks and creates a natural swimming pool. The waves crash into the rocks creating a natural water show!.

Surfing
To the right of the rocks is a nice area for surfing! the breaks are even and the reef is not that far from shore.  Sandy bottom 

Food 
There a lot of cool spots to check out
 A long the way “Frituria” these are fried food favorites!  You can’t  go wrong. 

Safety
It was safe. I saw the police ride through. No one was walking the beach trying to sell you anything. The vendors if any have a tent setup outside the beach.  That sell tourist stuff. 

If you Respect the ocean and understand its force you will have a safe time. At least once a year someone losses their life here because they forget that and go beyond the safety of the rocks per Dio Louie.

Punta de las Figuras Light, Arroyo, Puer.review_summary: This has to be one of the prettiest lighthouses we've ever seen. It's in a fenced off community (I think). But we told the man at the gate we wanted to take a picture of the lighthouse and he let us in. We use the Waze App when we travel, just type in Punta Figuras Lighthouse and it will take you right to it. At this time we were there we weren't allowed inside, but if you like lighthouses it is definitely worth the side trip to find it.

Punta Guilarte Beach, Arroyo, Puerto Ric.name: Puerto Rico
Punta Guilarte Beach, Arroyo, Puerto Ric.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Punta Guilarte Beach, Arroyo, Puerto Ric.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Juan Ramón Loubriel Stadium, Bayamón, Pu.description: The festive city of San Juan is the perfect place to experience true Puerto Rican culture. Get to know its roots by exploring the vibrant neighborhood of El Viejo San Juan (Old San Juan), which consists mostly of Spanish colonial buildings. Flesh out your self-guided history lesson with a visit to El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th century citadel that’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Then reward yourself with a cooling dip at Luquillo or Carolina Beach, then a tasty tour of the Bacardi rum plant.

Parque de las Ciencias, Bayamón, Puerto.name: Parque De Las Ciencias By Toro Verde Power By Claro
Parque de las Ciencias, Bayamón, Puerto.review_summary:
On 1 January 2025, I reserved/purchased three tickets for "El Show de Luces" at 6pm. On that same day there were still areas affected by the power outage in Puerto Rico. First, I posted a message on the main page of El Parque de Las Ciencias. A representative replied to my message that they would sent me a direct message. On FB Messenger a representative confirmed that the event was canceled; however none of their social platforms were advising the public of a potentially/confirmatory cancellation of the event. At that point, I requested a again a refund because I was limited to reschedule. Their policy is to offer no refunds, so they offered me to reschedule for the following day, 2 January 2025. I rescheduled my time to attend the event at 6pm. However, at the time of arrival on 2 January 2025, the representatives on site were telling us that they were just told that there had been an explosion in the area and that they were told at that time to cancel. I informed the representative that there had not been a communication to us about the cancelation of the event until the arrival. Therefore, again I requested a refund because this time a wasn't able to attend since I do not live in PR and was there for the holidays. Moving forward, the Customer Services Supervisor (Mayra Ortiz) told me that in this instant I would receive a refund. 

NOTE: The two cancelations were not because of me but because of the power outage and/or issues, which is not a weather issue, age/height/weight restrictions, not wearing appropriate shoes, or by being scared of the activity (see Toro Verde's policy). 

On the same night of 2 January 2025 at 9:02pm AST, I received a text that they understood the issue and had transferred my issue to the appropriate department with an expected date of refund between 7-14 days. 

On 16 January 2025, I contacted Toro Verde via text message since this had been the only option (outside of FB Messenger) to communicate with them. Their reply was that it would take 2-3 weeks for my refund. You note that it was a different answer specifically to time (e.g., adding more weeks).

Today, 24 January 2025, I decided to call Toro Verde at (787) 867-7100 to get an update. I requested a supervisor or the one in charge (i.e., los encargados as their staff refers to them). Tony Mendez from Toro Verde's Call Center could not find a supervisor within 10 minutes of putting me on hold. He then proceeded to check on my claim and let me know that "I was informed that I would not receive a refund." I replied to him to provide me a date/format (i.e., phone call, text, FB Messenger) of such communication to me since as of last week, everything was going to be refunded. He said, " I'm sorry but I am being honest, and that is what I am seeing on the screen." Nevertheless, I still requested a supervisor/"encargado" to discuss the issue but again no one was available. Tony, offered me to have my issue be transfered to a "supervisor/encargado" and for them to contact me. He replied that there wasn't anyone available. 
I kept on explaining to him thst my issue/claim was transferred on 2 January 2025 and no one has contacted me, outside of the times that I have contacted them. By the 23rd minute of the phone call he hung up the phone.

Like some other reviews for Toro Verde (i.e., zipline, The Beast, etc.), it seems that they do not care about the experience that you have but mainly about pushing the consumer to reschedule when at some point it is not plausible and reasonable (e.g., I do not live in PR, and the event was pushed to 2 February). Yes, they do have multiple good reviews of visitors who have successfully attended their activities. However, I cannot fathom the delay on such refund (e.g., since 2 January 2025) and the misinformation of now not receiving the refund. 

Furthermore, at no point there has been a verbal communication with me from any supervisor/encargado from Toro Verde to provide me of any updates to my refund. Every communication has started from my side and only today I was able to talk with a representative. 

Finally, would it not be easier to refund $83.07 for a unsatisfied customer who did not receive the service, outside of the merchant's policy, when there is a high demand for your services?

Thanks.

location_id.name: Ron del Barrilito Visitor Center
location_id.description: Hacienda Santa Ana is the home of Ron del Barrilito, the oldest rum in Puerto Rico. We offer several tours and experiences featuring our rum, which has been made here in the same way since 1880. Our Heritage Tour will take you around our historical landmarks and show you some of the methods we use to craft the world’s finest sipping rum. Our Tasting Tour is a unique opportunity to sip and enjoy all of our rums, from the cult-classic Three Stars to the extremely limited-edition Five Stars. Our Mixology Tour is an interactive class taught by superstar bartenders where you’ll improve your bartending game and learn to make show-stopping cocktails at home. Last but not least, here you’ll find the Ron del Barrilito Official Store, where you can purchase all of our rums and official merchandise not available anywhere else.

location_id.name: Isla de Ratones
location_id.review_summary: I look at dates to mention when I visited Isla de Ratones. Well this was back in 1970. I had to select one of the dates offered so my review can be posted. My aunt and her husband with some of their coworkers came with us. I remember when I looked over boat before arriving the water was crystal clear. You could literally see the ocean floor. It wasn’t what it is now, Of course. It’s been renovated.But still we had so much fun. This was on a summer vacation to Puerto Rico back then. I remember telling my friends at school that I’d walked the whole island and they were at awe. I remember finding different types fish while walking around the small island.  Beautiful place to go with family. I hope visitors keep the island clean and respect it’s beauty so that others can enjoy it as much as we did.

William Miranda Marín Botanical and Cult.name: Jardin Botanico y Cultural William Miranda Marin
William Miranda Marín Botanical and Cult.description: Take a stroll through the history of Puerto Rican roots and our ancestors in the Botanical Garden of Caguas! Here you can learn and admire about diverse fauna and flora and history in our island. In this protected garden you will find archeologic artifacts that used to belong our Taino ancestors. The remains of the Sugarcane factory Ingenio Azucar San Jose reside in this location along the remains of the centenary Barracon that is also on the location. The garden celebrates our diverse background that is composed of Taino , African and Spanish roots. The Botanical garden is located at only 30 minutes from San Juan. It is a beautiful park where you can either take a stroll and observe nature, meditate, or sight-see. The site is not only considered a garden, but also as a historic site, ecologic and historical museum.
William Miranda Marín Botanical and Cult.review_summary: Dont waste your gas coming here. Entrance is free, huge  government scientific plant/eco facility that is in great disrepair. You might think they would have crews cleaning up dead vegetation everywhere, ponds are dried up vandalism, no botanical gardens to speak of. A vegative wasteland.

Camuy Caves, Camuy, Puerto Rico.name: Parque Nacional de las Cavernas del Rio Camuy
Camuy Caves, Camuy, Puerto Rico.description: Tour some of the caves and sinkholes within this 268-acre park as you spot bats flying by and spiders crawling up and down the walls. Over 10 miles of limestone caves and underground rivers have been mapped so far, but only a small fraction of the entire network is open to the public. Wear closed shoes and get there early to secure a spot in the tour, which lasts a little more than an hour. When you’re done touring the caves, you can get a few souvenirs at the gift shop and grab a snack from a street vendor right outside. – Tripadvisor
Camuy Caves, Camuy, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Our family has tried to visit the park on December 22, 2024. The park was closed and the guard at the closed gate told us that it has been closed for 4 months until further notice. It is not allowed to enter neither the park nor the caves. There were dozens of cars which stopped at the gate while we were there only to leave in disappointment. We were standing near the gate for more than an hour researching if there was any other way to see the caves (with some tour or by entering through a different entrance to the caves). Unfortunately, no web-site states that the park is closed and the tour pages just say that their activity is not available at this time. So, it is not communicated to the public that one cannot visit the caves at this time. This is sad since quite a lot of people are likely visiting Puerto Rico to see the caves and consider them as one of the island's main attractions, as it was in our case.

Tres Pueblos Sinkhole, Camuy, Puerto Ric.name: Tres Pueblos Sinkhole
Tres Pueblos Sinkhole, Camuy, Puerto Ric.description: A 400-foot deep sinkhole in the Rio Camuy Cave Park.
Tres Pueblos Sinkhole, Camuy, Puerto Ric.review_summary: If you like to hike around and see some good nature than this is for you. Make sure you have some good shoes on, it can be very slippery. After check out some places around there to eat or have a drink.

Canóvanas Pueblo and its plaza, Canóvana.name: Canovanas
Canóvanas Pueblo and its plaza, Canóvana.review_summary: Absolutely amazing place. My friends and I were driving around looking for somewhere to eat, we found this place and Google and decided go give it a shot and I'm happy we did because it was delicious. The mofongo, sauces, lemonade, all of it was delicious. I wish I could've taken it home with me, especially the strawberry lemonade. Our server Jeriel was so attentive and kind, he made sure everything was to our liking and gave excellent service. I actually almost forgot to write this review, it's been a few weeks since I went but the service and food were so good I had to make sure I left a review. Highly recommend.

Camarero Racetrack, Canóvanas, Puerto Ri.name: Hipodromo Camarero
Camarero Racetrack, Canóvanas, Puerto Ri.description: Beautiful studio ocean view with balcony facing the ocean ,completely remodeled apartment,100% hotel facilities,concierge,front desk,mini-market,wifi-extra cost at the lobby,beach access,swimming pool, security 24-7 on duty.Rates per night 125.00 a nightcheck in 1.00pm check out 11.00 am.
Camarero Racetrack, Canóvanas, Puerto Ri.review_summary: We were travelling in Puerto Rico and seen the information of the track.  We thought would be fun. We went to track and it’s free to get in. We watched all the races and it was so much fun doing small bets on the horses.

Downtown Carolina and its main plaza, Ca.name: Carolina
Downtown Carolina and its main plaza, Ca.description: Once an important center for sugar production, Puerto Rico's fourth largest city's current fortunes come from its factories. Intriguing nicknames for the city of nearly 200,000 include The Land of Giants and Arm Hackers Town. Situated on the island's north shore, this Atlantic city is considered part of the metropolitan San Juan area. Popular attractions include Carolina Beach, Casa Escute art gallery, Caribbean Raceway Park and Isla Verde Mall. To make the most of your visit, consider renting a car.
Downtown Carolina and its main plaza, Ca.review_summary: All 4 of our group loved the food, the flavors and portions are exceptional. We’re here for 5 days and may eat breakfast here every morning. The service was also top notch and the decor has a cool vibe. 5 stars across the board.

location_id.name: Puerto Rico
location_id.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
location_id.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Isla Verde hotel and beach area, Carolin.name: Courtyard Isla Verde Beach Resort
Isla Verde hotel and beach area, Carolin.description: Newly renovated Courtyard by Marriott Isla Verde Beach Resort is located on a powdery expanse of Isla Verde beach in Carolina, Puerto Rico, the perfect location for business or pleasure. The first hotel in San Juan to offer FREE Internet & wireless services it makes business a breeze! For families, babysitting & play services, game room & the beautiful pool & beach make any holiday perfect. Enjoy our setting just a short distance from Old San Juan, El Yunque rainforest and more.
Isla Verde hotel and beach area, Carolin.review_summary: This resort was great, it is very convenient for 1st time tourists because it’s 5 mins away from the airport. The beach was awesome! My husband got in the beach many times and he loved it. The place was clean and the employees there were very nice and attentive. I will recommend this resort to other people.

Loíza River Boardwalk, Carolina, Puerto.name: Loiza
Loíza River Boardwalk, Carolina, Puerto.review_summary:
We had a very nice experience at El Nuevo Acuario. We had excellent service which was refreshing. We had very poor service at some other restaurants.
Appetizers were wonderful. The lobster empanadas were tasty, not greasy and full of favor. Grouper bites were fried with a sweetish sauce. The  main courses were good but not great. The fried red snapper was a little over done but the skin was salty and nicely crisp. The grouper was nicely cooked and very tasty. The sides were wanting. Too much rice and slightly watery beans.
We would go again for drinks and appetizers and choose different sides with the main courses. It’s worth going for the fine service.

Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport,.name: Parque Luis Munoz Marin
Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport,.description: The renovated Luis Munoz Marin park is a spectacular area to spend a day with family. As you enter, you'll find two areas where kids can play with water. The central area has towers decorated with mosaics. The other area has a large pool that's decorated with mosaics and has water spouts. Amidst the other attractions, there is an elevated route where you can walk among trees and enjoy a view atop the park. One of the favorite areas for older attendees has an enormous spider that is larger than 20 feet of height. There are two areas for pets. There are various areas for children to play football. There is a mini field available for football players. If you enjoy walking through open and natural spaces, the park is surrounded by modern sidewalks and colorful seats. -ZeePuertoRico
Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport,.review_summary: The park is no nice and clean, lots of families enjoying. I went for the doggie areas, which are great, they have two smaller closed areas and one big one with benches big trees and doggie obstacles. There is a park attendant in the entrance of the larger doggie park keeping and eye on the area. Lots of staff working all around the park which is great too. I recommend this park for a nice walk, pets and families.

location_id.name: Casa Bacardi Puerto Rico
location_id.description: Discover BACARDI's history through a guided tour, become a rum maestro with the Rum Tasting Tour, or master the Mojito with an interactive Mixology Class!

Cayey Pueblo and its main plaza, Cayey,.name: Cayey
Cayey Pueblo and its main plaza, Cayey,.review_summary:
Don Juan Santos Torres is an inspiring figure, showcasing how passion and creativity can transform a lifetime of work into something extraordinary. Known as “The Flintstones of Guavate,” he turned his retirement into a vibrant new chapter, dedicating himself to crafting remarkable sculptures that reflect his artistry and cultural pride. His "sacred mountain" in Guavate, Puerto Rico, is home to his most iconic work: towering statues of the Three Wise Men, standing at an impressive 33 feet tall and visible from the Luis A. Ferré Highway.

These sculptures are not just an artistic marvel but also a testament to his devotion to preserving Puerto Rican traditions and history. By trading construction tools for his creative pursuits, Don Juan has left a legacy that will inspire future generations. 

Don Juan's work is full of cultural and personal significance, so learning more about his story would only make the experience richer. His journey from construction worker to an artist is deeply tied to his love for Puerto Rican traditions.

He reportedly began sculpting as a way to give back to his community and honor the heritage of Guavate. The Three Wise Men, or Los Tres Reyes Magos, are central figures in Puerto Rican culture, especially celebrated during Día de Reyes (Three Kings Day). By creating these monumental statues, Don Juan not only highlighted this tradition but also ensured it would have a lasting, visual presence for all who pass by.

Ceiba Pueblo and its plaza, Ceiba, Puert.name: Ceiba
Ceiba Pueblo and its plaza, Ceiba, Puert.review_summary: We needed a taxi to get us (11 family members raging in age from 9 to 76) from San Juan to the Ceiba ferry and back, along with ferry tickets. Island Breeze Taxi was amazing to work with. They got us everything we needed. Mike was our driver and he was very communicative. We ended up in a large van for our 11 family members. We didn't have seatbelts (island life, I guess!) so that might be something to consider. I would assume the smaller car taxis do. We would 100% use their service again!

Roosevelt Roads Naval Station, Ceiba, Pu.name: Roosevelt Roads Naval Station
Roosevelt Roads Naval Station, Ceiba, Pu.review_summary:
If you’re a pilot/aviation buff like me, old and abandoned military  bases like this might be something for you? Or anybody who likes to explore abandoned places.

This was a fairly large U.S Naval Air station until it closed in 2004. The airfield is still open as a civil field. The rest of the expansive base has been transformed into a nature/public recreational reserve.  

After 17 years of abandonment, nature has definitely taken its course. 

Most the base remains, but left to the elements for 17 years.  And at least one major hurricane. Shoppings plazas, theater, hotel, base housing, gas station, fuel depot, military buildings, hangars, etc. A small town. All abandoned and exposed to the elements as nature takes over. 

We spent three hours just driving around exploring.  Mostly unrestricted. The roads are still there. Just with nature taking over on some of the back roads. People out biking and enjoying themselves. Not many people, though, albeit the occasional biker or security patrol.  It was like we were the only ones out there.

location_id.name: Catarata Chorro de Dona Juana
location_id.review_summary:
This waterfall is one of the main attractions of the area of the Rio Toro Negro forest and nature preserve.
We had to park quite far away from the waterfall as the already very narrow road was very crowded.

El Campito is authentic and cozy 
the food and service are excellent.

The decor is very puerto rican style 
I loved it and to top it off Ms Mailyn
the owner and family made us feel so welcome. I highly recommend this beautiful place . 
Elian el meserito me avisó que mi orden estaba ya servida  perfecto servicio 🌺

location_id.name: Toro Negro State Forest
location_id.description: One of fourteen forest reserves on the island, which features the peak Cerro de Punta and a number of hiking trails.
location_id.review_summary: What a gorgeous forest! Sadly, the falls and bathroom at the entrypoint were closed though signs said it was open. In the end, it was so quiet while we were there so maybe that was because parts were closed? We enjoyed the Las Delicias falls and the Dona Juana falls - both were breathtaking. I would have liked to have found a website online with the hours and hikes in the forest, but no such luck. Maybe it is out there and I just missed it. Anyway, we enjoyed our visit.

Baños de Coamo , historic warm springs,.name: Hotel Banos de Coamo
Baños de Coamo , historic warm springs,.review_summary:
This was my second time after 18 years. It was a great surprise. A Municipal enterprise runs the facility. In excellent conditions. Two pools (warm and hot). A souvenir store. Restrooms. Changing rooms. Chairs tables very clean. Very friendly. Peaceful. Calm music. $3 under 60y. $1 up to 75 y. Children and seniors for free. 
Please come to visit this. You will
Love it.

Brava Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Flamenco Beach
Brava Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.description: This horseshoe-shaped bay is popular amongst travelers for its clear, calm and shallow waters, and flat white sand. There are food stalls that sell food and drinks, shower facilities, and umbrellas that you can rent. As you walk along the shores, spot Flamenco’s most iconic attraction: the abandoned World War tanks decked in graffiti—a reminder of the US Navy’s occupancy of Culebra. It's a popular day trip spot from San Juan, so expect it to be busier on the weekends. Have your day sorted with a tour of Culebra Island, which typically includes transfers to the island and activities like snorkeling. – Tripadvisor
Brava Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary: What a beautiful beach! I wish we would have had more time but this beach is worth the effort. Enjoyed lunch at the kiosks then headed into the beach and sat up camp. There is shade under the trees and the sand is amazing. The water is so blue. You can see down to the bottom with perfect clarity. White fishes were swimming around us. If you are in Puerto Rico, take the time to visit Culebra and enjoy this beach!

Cayo Luis Peña, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Culebra
Cayo Luis Peña, Culebra, Puerto Rico.description: Culebra is somewhat of the anti-tourist destination, harboring no large hotels or flashy vacation bells and whistles. The beaches are stunning stretches of white sand, great for sunning, windsurfing and diving. The culture and architecture are just as colorful as the waters of the bright blue sea. Stroll around downtown for a truly quaint afternoon activity.
Cayo Luis Peña, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
A little scary to drive to on a practically one lane road along the coast and through the hills but worth the drive.  When you arrive at the parking lot walk to the west and you’ll see a new boardwalk.  Take this to the far end ( about 200 meters) and you’ll come out to the broad sandy beach.  Water was clean here other than being roiled up by waves.  It plunged deep fairly close to shore probably due to the waves.  Often at the beaches near here we would encounter patches of seaweed but here it wasn’t bad and you could get into the water and easily avoid it.  

The only negative to this beach was when we were here there were strong easterly winds with big waves and a strong undertow.

The only negative to this beach was when we were here there were strong easterly winds with big waves and a strong undertow.

Culebra Town, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Culebra
Culebra Town, Culebra, Puerto Rico.description: Culebra is somewhat of the anti-tourist destination, harboring no large hotels or flashy vacation bells and whistles. The beaches are stunning stretches of white sand, great for sunning, windsurfing and diving. The culture and architecture are just as colorful as the waters of the bright blue sea. Stroll around downtown for a truly quaint afternoon activity.
Culebra Town, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
A little scary to drive to on a practically one lane road along the coast and through the hills but worth the drive.  When you arrive at the parking lot walk to the west and you’ll see a new boardwalk.  Take this to the far end ( about 200 meters) and you’ll come out to the broad sandy beach.  Water was clean here other than being roiled up by waves.  It plunged deep fairly close to shore probably due to the waves.  Often at the beaches near here we would encounter patches of seaweed but here it wasn’t bad and you could get into the water and easily avoid it.  

The only negative to this beach was when we were here there were strong easterly winds with big waves and a strong undertow.

Culebrita, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Culebrita
Culebrita, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Gammy, a retired Coast Guard officer, took us to Culebrita on his power boat. He and his wife were super kind and knowledgeable, and they ensured we had the time of our lives. The island is absolutely stunning and practically private. Gammy provided everything: beach chairs, umbrellas, two paddleboards, a cooler, snorkel gear, tips about where to go, a map... he even brought water for the bozos who didn't bring enough (hi, it's me.)

They picked us up and dropped us off at pre-arranged locations, which was incredibly helpful. The boat ride is smooth and the island is incredible. If you're in Culebra, DO NOT MISS a trip to Culebrita with Gammy. It beat Flamenco and Tamarindo for me (both of which are also absolutely lovely).

Thank you, Gammy! You rock!

Flamenco Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Flamenco Beach
Flamenco Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.description: This horseshoe-shaped bay is popular amongst travelers for its clear, calm and shallow waters, and flat white sand. There are food stalls that sell food and drinks, shower facilities, and umbrellas that you can rent. As you walk along the shores, spot Flamenco’s most iconic attraction: the abandoned World War tanks decked in graffiti—a reminder of the US Navy’s occupancy of Culebra. It's a popular day trip spot from San Juan, so expect it to be busier on the weekends. Have your day sorted with a tour of Culebra Island, which typically includes transfers to the island and activities like snorkeling. – Tripadvisor
Flamenco Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary: What a beautiful beach! I wish we would have had more time but this beach is worth the effort. Enjoyed lunch at the kiosks then headed into the beach and sat up camp. There is shade under the trees and the sand is amazing. The water is so blue. You can see down to the bottom with perfect clarity. White fishes were swimming around us. If you are in Puerto Rico, take the time to visit Culebra and enjoy this beach!

Zoni Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.name: Playa Zoni
Zoni Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.description: Located on the Northeastern coast of Culebra, visiting Zoni Beach will be one of the most amazing beach experiences you will have in Culebra. Zoni is just as beautiful as the famous Flamenco Beach due to its indistinguishable white sands and clear waters. However, unlike Flamenco but much like all other Culebra beaches, Zoni does not offer any amenities, such as bathrooms, parking, kiosks, etc. It's a lot less populated than Flamenco, therefore, considered a more peaceful environment. Zoni's waters are deep and you should expect some waves, especially during winter. But don't let that throw you off, Zoni Beach offers different beach activities for every visitor; there's a large open area for sunbathing, playing beach volleyball, soccer o tennis, among others. If you're visiting between April and June, don't forget to be on the lookout for turtle nesting sites! Although, of course, do not walk over them or play around them. Overall, Zoni Beach is an obvious alternative for people who want to get away from it all and enjoy a relaxing day at the beach.Information sourced from enculebra.com
Zoni Beach, Culebra, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This is a beach not many people who visit Culebra go to. That's because it is located "on the other side"! It is on the extreme East of the island, and you arrive there...when the road ends! However, it's a clean and open beach (it's actually a refuge for turtles and has a great signpost providing key information about their life and care! We walked up and down the shore, enjoying the weather, the views (Cayo Norte and Culebrita islands in front)...and the peace and tranquility that exists there (no ships or shops!...no loud music or chats!...). Come and enjoy it!

Casa del Rey Museum, Dorado, Puerto Rico.name: Dorado
Casa del Rey Museum, Dorado, Puerto Rico.description: Located on Puerto Rico’s north coast, Dorado is a resort town of relatively recent vintage. You’ll find luxury hotels and several championship golf courses. Of course, if you’re used to your local, scruffy public course, your score might suffer—gorgeous ocean views can be quite a distraction.
Casa del Rey Museum, Dorado, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Excellent experience, from the parking with Frankie, to your beautiful restaurant, the view is spectacular and the server Short thin, light skin young lady so sorry I forgot her name. She was amazing. We will be back.

Dorado Pueblo and its main plaza, Dorado.name: Dorado

Juan Boria Theatre, Dorado, Puerto Rico.name: San Juan
Juan Boria Theatre, Dorado, Puerto Rico.description: The festive city of San Juan is the perfect place to experience true Puerto Rican culture. Get to know its roots by exploring the vibrant neighborhood of El Viejo San Juan (Old San Juan), which consists mostly of Spanish colonial buildings. Flesh out your self-guided history lesson with a visit to El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th century citadel that’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Then reward yourself with a cooling dip at Luquillo or Carolina Beach, then a tasty tour of the Bacardi rum plant.
Juan Boria Theatre, Dorado, Puerto Rico.review_summary: The customer service was top notch!!!! I love how attentive and quickly the staff responded. Provided great communication and helpful.

Ojo del Buey Park, Dorado, Puerto Rico.name: The Bay of El Ojo del Buey
Ojo del Buey Park, Dorado, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Great place yo bring your family and enjoy a beautiful day at a beautiful beach, very walkable one side for swimming and snorkeling other side you can surf great play to tan hear music and relax

Cayo Icacos, Fajardo, Puerto Rico.name: Cayo Icacos
Cayo Icacos, Fajardo, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Icacos is so beautiful and definitely worth a trip. My friend and i used captain mingo and I would highly recommend. Captain mingo was punctual for drop off and pick up times. He also provided a small cooler and umbrella for us to use. Thanks captain mingo.

Cordillera Keys Barrier Reef Nature Rese.name: Fajardo
Cordillera Keys Barrier Reef Nature Rese.review_summary: Great coffees, great food, great people.  The pancake tacos were excellent.  All the potatoes (waffle and bravas) were perfectly cooked.  Highly recommend!

Isla Palomino and Palominito, Fajardo, P.description: A private island where Wyndham El Conquistador guests are often ferried for more water activities.
Isla Palomino and Palominito, Fajardo, P.review_summary:
Beautiful natural setting, water was clear, not service from El conquistador Resort to the Island was on point. The food at the island restaurant was delicious. Ervin our waiter was so nice, even brought a coconut flan to celebrate my niece’s birthday, everything was fresh and tasty. 
Thank you to all staff in the island you are amazing!!

Las Croabas Natural Reserve, Fajardo, Pu.name: Las Croabas
Las Croabas Natural Reserve, Fajardo, Pu.review_summary: The kayaking instructors were friendly and patient.  I am a senior and was slower than the rest of the kayakers.  One of the guides was kind enough to tether our kayak to his to help us navigate the dark waters.  I was disappointed to learn that the plankton were not in full bloom because it is winter so we saw very little bioluminescence.

Puerto Del Rey Marina, Fajardo, Puerto R.name: Marina Puerto del Rey
Puerto Del Rey Marina, Fajardo, Puerto R.review_summary: I love Fajardo!  From the El Conquistador, looking east to the sea Culebra is visible, on a super clear day you can even see St. Thomas!  The marina is nice, clean, well equipped, and relatively safe from most storms.  I wouldn't sleep well if a hurricane came and my boat was in the marina, but its pretty secure.

Pueblo de Florida, Florida, Puerto Rico.name: Puerto Rico
Pueblo de Florida, Florida, Puerto Rico.description: Home to sprawling beaches, retail centers, and activity parks, the resort town of Puerto Rico is one Gran Canaria’s more family-friendly destinations. Subtropical temperatures and sunny skies make an ideal climate to soak up rays on golden sands or explore the volanic coast.
Pueblo de Florida, Florida, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Different GF bottles beer really nice . 
Didn’t eat not sure if they do food . 
Service was decent and lots of people there ..

Cayos de Caña Gorda and Gilligan's Islan.name: Gilligan's Island
Cayos de Caña Gorda and Gilligan's Islan.description: This small mangrove island off the coast of Puerto Rico is home to beautiful undisturbed nature and calm waters. Here, you can swim or snorkel in crystal-clear waters where you'll be able to see schools of tropical fish swimming around. Rent a kayak to explore the intricate canals and surrounding islands while enjoying the tranquil ocean views which stretch for miles. There is also a picnic area on the north side of the island. You can join an all-inclusive boat tour and spend the day exploring both the land and sea with the experience of a trained guide. – Tripadvisor
Cayos de Caña Gorda and Gilligan's Islan.review_summary: We stayed at Copamarina Resort on the south coast of Puerto Rico near the town of Guanica. Here, we rented a tandem kayak for 2 hours to go out to Aurora Cay. We were the 1st to go out at 8:50 am. The water was calmer early that day, and the sun was not too hot yet. It took about us about 20 mins to reach the small island, and we beached on the north side. Pelicans and birds greeted us, and we saw a sign indicating it is a manatee zone. The snorkeling was good, but only go if you are a strong swimmer and an experienced kayaker. After a while, we explored the channels dividing the 2 cays. The waters were clear and warm. We saw a giant gar and birds of all types. The mangroves  protect this wildlife sanctuary. It was an unforgettable morning, and we hope to return one day soon. There are no facilities here, so be sure to pack all the needed essentials. The tides and wind worked in our favor upon our return. As we left, a couple of small boats arrived with visitors. We're adventurous and recommended the trip to anyone who can get out there.

Central Guánica Sugarcane Refinery, Guán.name: Guanica
Central Guánica Sugarcane Refinery, Guán.review_summary: Beautiful beach tucked into a small bay near the entrance to the Guanica Harbor.  Water seemed clean, a little murky from the waves roiling up the sand.  The park was kept up well, no trash, lots of shady spots and good parking.  The only problem here is right when you step into the water it is very rocky.  After a few steps it then is very sandy.  After we swam we had the crawl out so we wouldn’t get hurt on the rocks.  It would have been better if we had water shoes.  This is a great place to watch the sunset, picture perfect hills surrounded it.

location_id.name: Bosque Estatal de Guanica
location_id.description: The Guánica State Forest & Bioshpere Reserve (Bosque Estatal de Guánica, in Spanish) is an great example of a dry forest, as compared to the rain forests found elsewhere on the island. Covering almost 1,000 acres, it has been designated as a United Nations International Biosphere Reserve. The forest offers many well-maintained trails and is a bird-watcher’s paradise.
location_id.review_summary: We went to explore the forest and were welcomed by the Biologist Joshua who was eager to share his knowledge with us. He was very welcoming and even showed us some San Pedrito’s (Puerto Rican Tody) very close to the beginning of the trail. Gave us recommendations on closer routes to other attractions on the forest driving wise and over all an amazing trip.

location_id.name: Guayama
location_id.review_summary: Probably the best food we’ve had in Puerto Rico…absolutely amazing.   The Lobster Mac ‘n Cheese was incredible!  But everything was very very good, from drinks to entree!  Great atmosphere too!  And Ariana was an excellent server!  Next time want to save room for dessert. 😋

Cautiño House Museum, Guayama, Puerto Ri.review_summary: A beautiful, historic home on the old square in Guayama.  Wonderful, informative guide.  Worth a visit.  (But not at lunch time.  Museum closes for lunch 12 to 1 pm).

Jobos Bay National Estuarine Research Re.name: Rookery Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve
Jobos Bay National Estuarine Research Re.description: The Rookery Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve represents one of the few remaining undisturbed mangrove estuaries in North America. Rookery Bay's Environmental Learning Center is a state-of-the-art, air conditioned 16,500 square-foot facility with four research laboratories, classrooms, a 140-seat auditorium, and two story visitor center. The Environmental Learning Center offers a variety of hands-on experiences, including a 2,300-gallon aquarium and a marine life touch tank. Other displays in the learning center address coastal research, local history and ongoing conservation efforts within Rookery Bay. There is also a number of nature trails, a scenic overlook bridge, unique gift store, art gallery, and picnic area. Guided boat and kayak tours are offered seasonally from November to May. Check our website for more information.
Jobos Bay National Estuarine Research Re.review_summary: Robyn, our guide, was extremely knowledgeable and professional.  We highly recommend doing Forest Bathing.  Very calming.

Museum of Transportation of Puerto Rico,.name: Puerto Rico
Museum of Transportation of Puerto Rico,.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Museum of Transportation of Puerto Rico,.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

San Patricio Plaza, Guaynabo, Puerto Ric.name: San Patricio Plaza
San Patricio Plaza, Guaynabo, Puerto Ric.description: San Patricio Plaza is a 640,000 square feet, three-level enclosed shopping mall located in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico. The mall is located at the intersection of PR-2, PR-23, and PR-20, and has over 120 stores with its anchors being Kmart, T.J. Maxx, Bed, Bath & Beyond, Capri, Walgreens, PetSmart, Caribbean Cinemas and Office Depot.
San Patricio Plaza, Guaynabo, Puerto Ric.review_summary: San Patricio Plaza has many nice shops where you can get clothes (nice boutiques), shoes, jewelry, accessories, and many others.  They also have a nice variety of places to eat at their food court, and also some restaurants (Chilis, Macaroni & Grill) within the mall and several nice ones across the street (Olive Garden and Long Horn).  The movie theaters are awesome!!! Recently renovated and all have nice leather reclining chairs with tray tables where you can eat.  There is also a nice variety of food to order.   Nice experience.

Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Hati.name: Our Lady of Mt Carmel Church
Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Hati.review_summary:
there was no crowd in the early afternoon of a Sunday. perhaps Mass celebrations are scheduled later.

just like any other Catholic Churches in the country, this place of worship has a peaceful vibe and serenity. i whispered a thanksgiving prayer for setting foot for the first time.

the architecture is simple, nothing impressive compared to the baroque churches up north. its cream-colored facade devoid of any ornaments reflects that of the white ceiling inside which lacks any visual art as well.

there was a beggar carrying a sleeping child at the main door who was spewing expletives to the caretaker who was trying to make her leave. it was a painful sight. 

i heard about an apparition of the Blessed Virgin Mary that happened here some decades ago. i had bo idea if this was recognized by the Church authorities.

Hatillo Pueblo and its main plaza, Hatil.name: Hatillo
Hatillo Pueblo and its main plaza, Hatil.review_summary: We had issues with our GPS trying to send us down the wrong roads to get to this beach but had better luck putting Marilyn’s restaurant in Hatillo as destination and it will take you right to the parking lot. it was $3 to park for the day and guard said we could leave and come back with our ticket. The beach is great with a few little covered picnic tables and a large protected pool for swimming. There were some waves but it was safe for kids and we saw a few people snorkeling. Not a lot of shade though so plan accordingly for that. No permanent bathrooms but when we were there they had portapotty. Kind of a lot of trash in the parking area but the beach was clean.

Plaza del Norte, Hatillo, Puerto Rico.name: Hatillo
Plaza del Norte, Hatillo, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We had issues with our GPS trying to send us down the wrong roads to get to this beach but had better luck putting Marilyn’s restaurant in Hatillo as destination and it will take you right to the parking lot. it was $3 to park for the day and guard said we could leave and come back with our ticket. The beach is great with a few little covered picnic tables and a large protected pool for swimming. There were some waves but it was safe for kids and we saw a few people snorkeling. Not a lot of shade though so plan accordingly for that. No permanent bathrooms but when we were there they had portapotty. Kind of a lot of trash in the parking area but the beach was clean.

Basílica Menor de la Virgen de Monserrat.name: Basilica de Santa Maria de Guadalupe
Basílica Menor de la Virgen de Monserrat.description: This famous church, located on the site where an Indian claimed to have seen the Virgin of Guadalupe in 1531, contains an image of her that is the most famous religious icon in all of Mexico.
Basílica Menor de la Virgen de Monserrat.review_summary: Modern-ish church and square, both of huge and impressive size. A real family atmosphere with adults and children sitting and eating everywhere. A lovely place.

Casa Roig Museum, Humacao, Puerto Rico.name: Casa Roig Museum
Casa Roig Museum, Humacao, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This was at one time a beautiful home and does resemble Frank Lloyd Wright architecture. Unfortunately, Hurricane Maria damaged the home in 2017 and there are not funds currently for the necessary repairs. The home is not open for tours at the moment. There were some very helpful staff next door that showed us around and gave a lot of good information.

Humacao Cathedral, Humacao, Puerto Rico.name: Humacao
Humacao Cathedral, Humacao, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
The hotel itself is beautiful, the staff is super friendly and always helpful. Especially Efrain was a delight, very attentive and welcoming.
However there were unfortunately some big lacks. When we entered our room it was super moisty and smelled. We didn’t get rid of that during our stay. The bed was so wet it sticked to our skin. The Hotel in general wasn’t really clean. The food was average, the tables and chairs outside were dirty from the birds and the chairs haven’t been cleaned. For some days the area outside was closed due to a sports event, which was also very unfortunate. We then had to have breakfast inside where the air conditioner freezed us :/

Humacao Pueblo and its main plaza, Humac.name: Humacao
Humacao Pueblo and its main plaza, Humac.review_summary:
The hotel itself is beautiful, the staff is super friendly and always helpful. Especially Efrain was a delight, very attentive and welcoming.
However there were unfortunately some big lacks. When we entered our room it was super moisty and smelled. We didn’t get rid of that during our stay. The bed was so wet it sticked to our skin. The Hotel in general wasn’t really clean. The food was average, the tables and chairs outside were dirty from the birds and the chairs haven’t been cleaned. For some days the area outside was closed due to a sports event, which was also very unfortunate. We then had to have breakfast inside where the air conditioner freezed us :/

Palmas del Mar Resort and Beach, Humacao.name: Wyndham Palmas Beach & Golf Boutique Resort
Palmas del Mar Resort and Beach, Humacao.description: Located at the heart of one of Puerto Rico’s most exclusive residential communities, Palmas del Mar, Wyndham Palmas Beach & Golf Resort is an oasis full of character, energy and unique facilities. This boutique resort sits within two beautifully manicured golf courses and is surrounded by lush tropical gardens, just steps from the beach. The upscale, boutique resort features 107 rooms, a 6,000 square feet ballroom, an infinity pool and an additional family pool and beach style access. The multiple food and beverage options on property offer two bars, a wine cellar room, a wonderful restaurant featuring Puerto Rican and international cuisine and wood oven pizzas. The resort’s unique location within Palmas gives clients access to the many amenities the community has to offer, from an upscale Marina to world-class tennis facilities, two championship golf courses, an equestrian center, Pterocarpus forest and several restaurants that range from upscale French cuisine to casual local flair. The unique location in Puerto Rico’s East Coast, provides quick access to miles of unspoiled beaches and the El Yunque tropical rainforest, as well as Vieques and Culebra islands via quick flights from Ceiba airport. Wyndham Palmas Beach and Golf Resort captures the best of the Caribbean with world-class amenities.
Palmas del Mar Resort and Beach, Humacao.review_summary:
The hotel itself is beautiful, the staff is super friendly and always helpful. Especially Efrain was a delight, very attentive and welcoming.
