location_id.name: Guajataca Forest Reserve
location_id.review_summary: This was a calm activity where you could explore the beautiful tropical scenery in Puerto Rico in a pristine & quiet environment.

Guajataca Tunnel and beach, Isabela, Pue.name: Tunel de Guajataca
Guajataca Tunnel and beach, Isabela, Pue.description: Built in 1911 for sugarcane trains. The western end of the tunnel connects to the Playa El Pastillo.
Guajataca Tunnel and beach, Isabela, Pue.review_summary: Absolutely gorgeous! My favorite spot we visited! We were there at sunset but would be a great beach day! Waves are strong so be careful swimming but there is also a natural pool on the beach for children to play in. So much beauty in one spot! Vendors set up during the day and I highly recommend the passion fruit mojitos!  My son and I loved exploring along the beach!

Hermitage of San Antonio de Padua de la.name: San Antonio de Areco
Hermitage of San Antonio de Padua de la.description: A compact small town nearly 70 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, San Antonio de Areco is in the heart of the Argentine Pampas region. It’s a great 1½-hour day trip by car or bus from Buenos Aires—or the perfect jumping-off point for those who choose to visit at a nearby estancia, or a traditional large rural ranch and estate. Major attractions here include the colonial sights of San Antonio de Areco itself, the Museum of the Gaucho (which celebrates Argentine cowboys), and a variety of estancias themselves, which are located within two hours of San Antonio de Areco. If you don’t feel like planning your own itinerary, several tour and travel companies will coordinate your visit and arrange your estancia stay.
Hermitage of San Antonio de Padua de la.review_summary: We did a day trip to the estancia. The staff was very attentive except the horseback riding staff. The ride itself was NOT as advertised. We basically rode a large circle in a pasture, and it lasted about 20 minutes. The food was delicious, and the grounds were beautiful. If you are wanting a great horseback riding experience, this estancia is not the place.

Isabela Pueblo and its main plaza, Isabe.name: Isabela
Isabela Pueblo and its main plaza, Isabe.review_summary: Had high hopes for this one based on the reviews for snorkeling, but it was just ok. I did go the same weekend as a tsunami warning so that’s probably why the current was strong and i didn’t feel 100% comfy going out by myself. I did go in and stayed close to shore, it ended up ok but i didn’t see that much. Ultimately other places better for snorkeling in the north/west. Also parking is limited to like 5 spots total, easy to drive right past the grassy nook but there is a sign once you look closely. No street parking. A friendly dog escorted us from parking to the beach, how nice! Only stayed a short time to check out other spots.

Jobos Beach, Isabela, Puerto Rico.name: Jobos Beach
Jobos Beach, Isabela, Puerto Rico.description: This beach on the northwest coast offers an interesting combination of mild waters, perfect for families with children, and rough water perfect for surfers, plus opportunities for fishing, snorkeling, scuba diving, wind surfing and canoeing.
Jobos Beach, Isabela, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Arrival on a Sunday afternoon in February was hectic. The road was full of cars on both sides, major traffic, people rent their private property nearby for extra parking. First walking out onto the sand, no spots too crowded, but if you walk away down the beach there is less people. The volleyball court was active, surfers everywhere, pickleball in the sand - lots happening here. Reviews from others got me nervous about going in the water here. Everyone talks about the strong currents and how many have drowned or needing saving. I did go in and I can attest the current is strong. I stayed very cautious close to shore with my snorkel. Surfers including young kids on their boards well out into the big waves. It’s so tempting to go out that way but not a casual swim. I did see some fish clearly in the areas I swam which was nice.

La Pocita de las Golondrinas Beach, Isab.name: La Poza De Las Golondrinas
La Pocita de las Golondrinas Beach, Isab.review_summary:
Excellent for surfers and expert swimmers, except for the small poza.  

Enjoyed the beautiful views and took some photos. There was one guy selling coconuts nearby, and there are also several restaurants within a mile of the beach. A good place for getting away from the everyday routine.  Limited number of shades, really warm.

Pozo de Jacinto, Isabela, Puerto Rico.name: Pozo de Jacinto
Pozo de Jacinto, Isabela, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This is located in Jobos beach  and there 8s a legend about why is named la Poza de Jacinto; you can look it up. It's a great spot for pictures. Be careful getting to close to the edges because it can be very dangerous.

Cerro de Punta, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.name: Cerro de Punta
Cerro de Punta, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.description: The tallest mountain is in the center of the island, which at an elevation of 4,389 feet with an area of 3,515 square miles, offers spectacular vistas of the entire island and Caribbean Sea.
Cerro de Punta, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Park by the main road. Hike up is about a mile. Do not attempt to drive up. The road is very narrow and looks washed out. Huge craters and loose gravel.
I am sharing the photos of the road for those who are thinking of driving up.

Cerro Rosa, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.name: Jayuya
Cerro Rosa, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Food was authentic and absolutely delicious! We visit PR regularly and this was our best meal; the owner is the chef and his pride is evident!

Jayuya Pueblo and its main plaza, Jayuya.name: Jayuya
Jayuya Pueblo and its main plaza, Jayuya.review_summary: Food was authentic and absolutely delicious! We visit PR regularly and this was our best meal; the owner is the chef and his pride is evident!

Los Tres Picachos, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.name: Cafe Tres Picachos
Los Tres Picachos, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Excellent food and coffee/mocha “Frape”.  Location is a very nice setting.  14oz 100% Jayuya coffee bags very well priced at $4.25.   I purchased 6 bags,  two for my kids who live stateside.

Los Tres Picachos State Forest, Jayuya,.name: Cafe Tres Picachos
Los Tres Picachos State Forest, Jayuya,.review_summary: Excellent food and coffee/mocha “Frape”.  Location is a very nice setting.  14oz 100% Jayuya coffee bags very well priced at $4.25.   I purchased 6 bags,  two for my kids who live stateside.

Monte Jayuya, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.name: Jayuya
Monte Jayuya, Jayuya, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Food was authentic and absolutely delicious! We visit PR regularly and this was our best meal; the owner is the chef and his pride is evident!

Nemesio Canales House and El Cemí Museum.name: Museo El Cemi
Nemesio Canales House and El Cemí Museum.description: The museum features archeological artifacts from the Taino culture. Casa Canales belonged to the Canales family, founders of the town and participants in the 1950 Revolution.
Nemesio Canales House and El Cemí Museum.review_summary: Very nice,well kept Indian museum in Puerto Rico,very nice and peaceful with nice parking and restaurants. Nice native places and native artifacts...

Piedra Escrita petroglyphs and natural p.name: La Piedra Escrita
Piedra Escrita petroglyphs and natural p.description: This place is naturally beautiful. A monumental stone with important petroglyphs allows you to get in touch with the Taino culture and its enviroment. A popular spot for bathing in the river and cooling off.
Piedra Escrita petroglyphs and natural p.review_summary: Beautiful!!  The mountain roads made getting there is a bit of a challenge but well worth it!  The views are amazing.  Unless you are highly skilled with a stick shift, an automatic transmission car is recommended.

Juncos Pueblo and its main plaza, Juncos.name: Juncos
Juncos Pueblo and its main plaza, Juncos.review_summary:
Great atmosphere, great food and great service! Far surpassed my expectations!!!
I highly recommend this experience. It was a Puerto Rican highlight!

Isla Magueyes, Lajas, Puerto Rico.name: Puerto Rico
Isla Magueyes, Lajas, Puerto Rico.description: Home to sprawling beaches, retail centers, and activity parks, the resort town of Puerto Rico is one Gran Canaria’s more family-friendly destinations. Subtropical temperatures and sunny skies make an ideal climate to soak up rays on golden sands or explore the volanic coast.
Isla Magueyes, Lajas, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Different GF bottles beer really nice . 
Didn’t eat not sure if they do food . 
Service was decent and lots of people there ..

Isla Mata la Gata, Lajas, Puerto Rico.name: Isla Mata La Gata
Isla Mata la Gata, Lajas, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Swimming in these warm waters was wonderful. The mangroves protect the area so the waters are very calm and clear like a swimming pool! We toured in August and the waters were like bath water…the island is very small but has a short boardwalk to walk around…a few picnic tables. The waters are not very deep-perhaps 5-6 feet.

La Parguera, Lajas, Puerto Rico.name: La Parguera
La Parguera, Lajas, Puerto Rico.description: This fishing village is home to nature reserves, pristine cays, and one of Puerto Rico’s three bioluminescent bays—the only one that you can swim in. Here, you can grab some food at the town's main square, enjoy views of the Caribbean Sea, kayak around Cayo Caracoles and Cayo Mata La Gata, go wildlife spotting, and snorkel and dive in the tropical waters rich with marine life. The main highlight here is the bioluminescent bay—join a boat tour to see the glowing waters and dive in for a swim. Visit during a new moon and the warmer months when the bay glows the brightest. – Tripadvisor
La Parguera, Lajas, Puerto Rico.review_summary: In the morning, we did the pedal kayaking, which was fantastic! Gabriel was a wonderful guide and did not rush us at all. The views were amazing and the water crystal clear. In the evening we did the swimming in the bioluminescent bay and that was excellent! we had so much fun seeing our T-shirts sparkle from the plankton. It was as if they had glitter on them.

Laguna Cartagena National Wildlife Refug.name: Vieques National Wildlife Refuge
Laguna Cartagena National Wildlife Refug.description: Much of the land on this new wildlife reserve was once a naval bombing range.
Laguna Cartagena National Wildlife Refug.review_summary: This is a most amazing place. If you are looking for comfy beach chairs and all the creature comforts of a vacation resort, this is not it. If you want to experience the land, the beach, the sea...just as it IS...this is the place. We took our rental Jeep back the windy road and spread our towels under the coconut trees and enjoyed a beach without another human in sight or hearing. Just us and Mother Nature. It is a top ten highlight of my life, truly. Just the most natural and peaceful setting.

Lajas Pueblo and its main plaza, Lajas,.name: Lajas
Lajas Pueblo and its main plaza, Lajas,.review_summary: This was SO special visiting the bio Bay! Our famile had the best time ever swimming and kayaking! We were a bit nervous about how much we could see as full moon were the day after our visit but we were not disappointed at all. The Crew on board were so pleasant.

Puerto Rico Alien Route, Lajas, Puerto R.name: Puerto Rico
Puerto Rico Alien Route, Lajas, Puerto R.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Puerto Rico Alien Route, Lajas, Puerto R.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Castañer Pueblo and its former city hall.name: Lares
Castañer Pueblo and its former city hall.review_summary: We hadn't been here for years and were delighted to find it unchanged, busy, and still with an amazing variety of flavors including unusual ones such as rice and beans.  I had soursop and dulce de leche. My husband had tamarindo and mango. On the square in Lares, not to be confused with Heladeria El Grito which also serves ice cream.  Friendly servers and they freely offer tastes before you commit to a flavor.  Many framed vintage newspaper articles on the walls about the history of Lares.

Hacienda Lealtad, Lares, Puerto Rico.name: Hacienda Lealtad
Hacienda Lealtad, Lares, Puerto Rico.review_summary: I scheduled a tour online and my card was charged immediately.  Received a confirmation text.  On day of tour, entire family leaves sunny San Juan for a 2 hour drive to Hacienda Lealtad. It is raining lightly when we arrived about an hour before tour scheduled and forecast showed it was   clearing up. At the gate, guard informs us that all tours were canceled due to the rain.  I had not received a call or text to notify me of this.  After being turned away at the gate, I called the office and they  confirmed that all tours were canceled due to heavy thunderstorms.   She was unable to refund my card and had to take my information to give to the refund department?  Not sure when or if I will get refunded,  but a precious vacation day was wasted driving 4 hours for nothing when a simple text or call from the establishment could have prevented it.

Lares Ice Cream Parlor, Lares, Puerto Ri.name: Lares
Lares Ice Cream Parlor, Lares, Puerto Ri.review_summary: We hadn't been here for years and were delighted to find it unchanged, busy, and still with an amazing variety of flavors including unusual ones such as rice and beans.  I had soursop and dulce de leche. My husband had tamarindo and mango. On the square in Lares, not to be confused with Heladeria El Grito which also serves ice cream.  Friendly servers and they freely offer tastes before you commit to a flavor.  Many framed vintage newspaper articles on the walls about the history of Lares.

Lares Pueblo and its main plaza, Lares,.name: Lares
Lares Pueblo and its main plaza, Lares,.review_summary: We hadn't been here for years and were delighted to find it unchanged, busy, and still with an amazing variety of flavors including unusual ones such as rice and beans.  I had soursop and dulce de leche. My husband had tamarindo and mango. On the square in Lares, not to be confused with Heladeria El Grito which also serves ice cream.  Friendly servers and they freely offer tastes before you commit to a flavor.  Many framed vintage newspaper articles on the walls about the history of Lares.

Cueva del Indio Archaeological Site, Las.name: Cueva Del Indio
Cueva del Indio Archaeological Site, Las.description: An important site within indigenous Taíno culture, Cueva del Indio is home to a beautiful selection of prehistoric cave art on Puerto Rico’s Atlantic coast. Admire over 80 pre-Columbian indigenous petroglyphs made on the cave’s limestone walls between 1200 and 1500 A.D., and learn more about the island’s indigenous cultures. The scenic hike to the cave also boasts pretty coastal views and impressive grassy cliffs. You might want to join a tour that departs from San Juan—it's a great way combine your visit to the cave with other attractions in the area, such as the Cueva Ventana and the Arecibo Observatory. – Tripadvisor
Cueva del Indio Archaeological Site, Las.review_summary:
A nice stop along the northern shore.  I read the conflicting reviews about parking.  All beaches in PR are free, and you can find a place to park.  If you do decide to park for free, do it on the east side of the arch (before you get to the paid lot).  That said, we paid to park and it gives you a good spot to start (and there are porta potties).   

We went to the cave and then the arch.  My family is adventurous and I would not recommend going into the cave.  Once you get to the bottom, which is about 20 feet down, it's a small space and there isn't much to see or explore. 5 minutes down there and you are ready to go out.  However, there is the problem.  The entry hole is small and "one-way", so if a tour group is behind you then you could be stuck down there for a while. This happened to us.   The tour guides were very rude.  They would not the 2 of us get out before they got their people through the opening.  That said, there is a trick to getting out if you have the ability to climb.  If you at the bottom and are facing the carvings on the wall, turn to your right and there is a pocket that you can enter and climb up and out. My son is 12 and was the one to figure it out.  It's was fairly easy to do but do so at your own risk.  We saw another couple later in the day and they said they were stuck down there for about 40 minutes, as they were not comfortable with the climb.  Also as you walk around up top, there are about 5 holes that are the size of a manhole cover.  If you fall through it's not going to end well.  Do not walk and take pictures at the same time.  Pay attention.

We then worked east toward the beach/arch.  It is a easy, short hike that leads to some very nice views.

Overall a nice spot - but think twice about the cave if it is crowded.

Church of the Holy Spirit and San Patric.name: Loiza
Church of the Holy Spirit and San Patric.review_summary:
We had a very nice experience at El Nuevo Acuario. We had excellent service which was refreshing. We had very poor service at some other restaurants.
Appetizers were wonderful. The lobster empanadas were tasty, not greasy and full of favor. Grouper bites were fried with a sweetish sauce. The  main courses were good but not great. The fried red snapper was a little over done but the skin was salty and nicely crisp. The grouper was nicely cooked and very tasty. The sides were wanting. Too much rice and slightly watery beans.
We would go again for drinks and appetizers and choose different sides with the main courses. It’s worth going for the fine service.

Julia de Burgos Park, Carolina, Puerto R.name: Puerto Rico
Julia de Burgos Park, Carolina, Puerto R.description: Home to sprawling beaches, retail centers, and activity parks, the resort town of Puerto Rico is one Gran Canaria’s more family-friendly destinations. Subtropical temperatures and sunny skies make an ideal climate to soak up rays on golden sands or explore the volanic coast.
Julia de Burgos Park, Carolina, Puerto R.review_summary:
Different GF bottles beer really nice . 
Didn’t eat not sure if they do food . 
Service was decent and lots of people there ..

Loíza Pueblo and its main plaza, Loíza,.name: Loiza
Loíza Pueblo and its main plaza, Loíza,.review_summary:
We had a very nice experience at El Nuevo Acuario. We had excellent service which was refreshing. We had very poor service at some other restaurants.
Appetizers were wonderful. The lobster empanadas were tasty, not greasy and full of favor. Grouper bites were fried with a sweetish sauce. The  main courses were good but not great. The fried red snapper was a little over done but the skin was salty and nicely crisp. The grouper was nicely cooked and very tasty. The sides were wanting. Too much rice and slightly watery beans.
We would go again for drinks and appetizers and choose different sides with the main courses. It’s worth going for the fine service.

Piñones village and food kiosks, Loíza,.name: Playa Pinones
Piñones village and food kiosks, Loíza,.description: Just a 20-minute drive from the airport, Pinones is a bustling coastal area with amazing scenery, beaches, and food—a great pitstop right after you land or before you leave. Try local Puerto Rican food from the snack shacks and bars that line the streets. Grab your food and head to a nearby beach for a picnic, and then hop on a bike or stroll along the boardwalk.
Piñones village and food kiosks, Loíza,.review_summary: Piñones is one of the top places I would recommend if travelling to PR. It has it all; beches, great food, a beach that looks like a pool, a huge cave (Maria de la Cruz), trails, kayak renting, etc.

Piñones State Forest, Loíza, Puerto Rico.name: Playa Pinones
Piñones State Forest, Loíza, Puerto Rico.description: Just a 20-minute drive from the airport, Pinones is a bustling coastal area with amazing scenery, beaches, and food—a great pitstop right after you land or before you leave. Try local Puerto Rican food from the snack shacks and bars that line the streets. Grab your food and head to a nearby beach for a picnic, and then hop on a bike or stroll along the boardwalk.
Piñones State Forest, Loíza, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Piñones is one of the top places I would recommend if travelling to PR. It has it all; beches, great food, a beach that looks like a pool, a huge cave (Maria de la Cruz), trails, kayak renting, etc.

La Pared Beach, Luquillo, Puerto Rico.name: Playa La Pared
La Pared Beach, Luquillo, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This is a beautiful beach that is popular with surfers, but people really underestimate the danger here.  There are significant rip currents and no life guards.  Yesterday a 26 year old tourist was lost in a rip current and we watched the coast guard and local rescue teams search for hours to no avail.  Just last week another adult male tourist drowned shortly after a surfing lesson.  You really need to know what you’re doing to swim or surf at a beach like this.

Luquillo Beach and its food kiosks, Luqu.name: Luquillo Kiosks
Luquillo Beach and its food kiosks, Luqu.review_summary: Major let down. Thought it would be cute beach shops, snacks, restaurants. It’s Mostly bars, some low-end souvenir shops, lot of closed kiosks which collect garbage and smell like outdoor baños. The beach itself is pretty.

Luquillo Pueblo and its main plaza, Luqu.name: Luquillo
Luquillo Pueblo and its main plaza, Luqu.review_summary: We had an incredible stay at The Serene House in Puerto Rico, a beautiful bed and breakfast owned by Pablo and Maribel. The atmosphere truly lives up to its name—calm, serene, and perfect for a peaceful retreat. The rooms and casitas are impeccably clean and thoughtfully designed for comfort. One of the highlights of our stay was the gourmet breakfast, which was absolutely delicious and carefully prepared. If you’re looking for a relaxing and rejuvenating getaway, Serenity House is the perfect choice!

Hacienda La Esperanza, Manatí, Puerto Ri.name: Hacienda La Esperanza
Hacienda La Esperanza, Manatí, Puerto Ri.description: Follow the historical trajectory of Hacienda La Esperanza Nature Reserve in Manati, one of Puerto Rico’s most prosperous sugar plantations during the 19th Century, where the main driving force behind sugar production was slavery. During this tour, you will visit the different structures that make up La Esperanza’s Historical Site, including the Sugar Mill and its unique 1861 West Point Foundry steam engine. Spaces are limited, please reserve in advance online or by phone. Facilities for the handicapped are limited because of uneven terrain.
Hacienda La Esperanza, Manatí, Puerto Ri.review_summary:
Llegamos a la Hacienda La Esperanza alrededor de las 10:30 a.m. (según su sitio web, abren de 8 a.m. a 4 p.m.) este pasado Martes 12 de Febrero y fuimos recibidos por un guardia, quien nos informó que no podían dejarnos entrar ya que no había suficiente personal. Inmediatamente sugirió que regresáramos otro día. Le expliqué que manejamos un poco más de dos horas para llegar allí y que era extremadamente decepcionante que debido a problemas de personal no nos permitieran entrar luego de haber echo tan largo viaje. Pregunté: ¿habrá suficiente personal en el futuro? y su respuesta fue “no podía estar seguro de eso”.
Estábamos muy entusiasmados con poder visitar la antigua hacienda y su falta de personal/consideración nos arruinó el día. Espero que en un futuro sean más consientes y mantengan sus instalaciones con personal adecuado para poder atender a todo visitante. También les sugiero que si están teniendo dificultades para poder atender el público lo informen en su página web y/o redes sociales para que así todo aquel que esté considerado visitarles tenga esto en mente. De lo contrario les sugiero que no habrán sus puertas.

English translation.

We arrived at Hacienda La Esperanza around 10:30 a.m. (according to their website, they are open from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.) this past Tuesday, February 12, and we were greeted by a guard, who informed us that they could not let us in since there were not enough staff. He immediately suggested we come back another day. I explained that we drove a bit over two hours to get there and that it was extremely disappointing that due to staffing issues we were not allowed in after such a long trip. I asked: will there be enough staff in the future? and his response was “I couldn't be sure of that.”
We were very excited to visit the old hacienda and their lack of staff/consideration ruined our day. I hope that in the future they will be considerate and maintain their facilities with adequate staff in order to be able to serve all visitors. I also suggest that if they are having staffing issues, they inform them on their website and/or social media so that everyone who is considering visiting them has this in mind. Otherwise they shouldn’t bother opening their doors.

Manatí Pueblo and its main plaza, Manatí.name: Manati
Manatí Pueblo and its main plaza, Manatí.review_summary:
El Campito is authentic and cozy 
the food and service are excellent.

The decor is very puerto rican style 
I loved it and to top it off Ms Mailyn
the owner and family made us feel so welcome. I highly recommend this beautiful place . 
Elian el meserito me avisó que mi orden estaba ya servida  perfecto servicio 🌺

Mar Chiquita Beach, Manatí, Puerto Rico.name: Playa Mar Chiquita
Mar Chiquita Beach, Manatí, Puerto Rico.review_summary: A paradise on earth, sad that you find some trash on its marvellous sands. Anyway suggest people to visit this lovely place in Puerto Rico.

Hacienda Juanita, Maricao, Puerto Rico.name: Hacienda Juanita
Hacienda Juanita, Maricao, Puerto Rico.description: Hacienda Juanita is an antique coffee plantation located in Maricao, Puerto Rico. It was built with a Spanish style.
Hacienda Juanita, Maricao, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Excellent service. Best of all the coffee I was just waiting to wake up to drink that awesome coffee. The breakfast was spectacular and the lunch. The people on town is very friendly. We have a good time. And the climate very nice. Hope to come back.

Maricao Fish Hatchery, Maricao, Puerto R.name: Maricao
Maricao Fish Hatchery, Maricao, Puerto R.review_summary:
This is our review of the Forest Service Headquarters located in the Maricao Forest Preserve at the 16.1km marker on highway PR-120.
I would think this location is primarily of interest for birders, as several local endemics are present.
The entrance road turns off PR-120 and parallels it for awhile before it comes to an open area that has picnic shelters (pretty run down) and bathrooms that are locked when we were there. A gate keeps you out of the actual HQ buildings where people are working. For birding, the road in is worth walking and they've lined the road with benches for you to sit and let the birds show up.
There is parking near the bathrooms, but you can also continue up to the overlook (Banco Solitario) although there are some deep holes that make it somewhat hard to turn around. The overlook has two benches, giving you options for shade, and the view is wonderful for a picnic or rest.
Behind the bench across the road, there is a very short, straight trail that is worth birding.
The road winds up past electrical transformers and ends at a gate. You can walk past the gate and should, as it goes up to an old stone house (Casa De Piedra) in another clearing. A trail keeps going past the house and if you take the right hand path, it seems to go downhill a lot. There are nature info signs that seem new. Not knowing where this trail went (there are no maps), we were a little worried we'd have to backtrack and climb back up, but somehow magically we came out just a little below the lookout benches on the road up to them. This apparently is called the "old jeep road", and you'll notice the other end on the way up to the lookout, on your right behind a yellow gate.  Actually a nice trail.
The left hand trail I've read follows a powerline cut that goes upward and rejoins PR-120 at KM 15.3.

Maricao Pueblo and its main plaza, Maric.review_summary:

Maunabo Pueblo and its main plaza, Mauna.name: Maunabo
Maunabo Pueblo and its main plaza, Mauna.review_summary:
I asked our guest service rep about public beaches in the area and she recommended Playa Mario, a 25 minute drive from Palmas Del Mar.  the trip to get there was an adventure, up and down mountains on a single lane with 
sharp ess curves.  Once we hit the mountaintop, the view was breathtaking.  Even more spectacular was the fact that shared the whole beach the perhaps three other couples the whole five hours we were there.  Nice palm tree line for shade.  We were a bit disconcerted when we saw a pack of ferrel dogs running along the beach…they were playfully charging at ducks both in and out of the water.  I jumped in the car when they were getting close but they passed by without incident, even with our things sitting on the beach.  Two later came back and slept within two feet of us without coming closer nor looking for pets or food.  A great quiet afternoon.

Punta Tuna Lighthouse, Maunabo, Puerto R.name: Punta Tuna Lighthouse
Punta Tuna Lighthouse, Maunabo, Puerto R.description: Built in 1892. It is located on the southeast tip of the island. This lighthouse integrates the system of lighthouses of the east with the lighthouses of the south of the island. Its structure corresponds to the neoclassical style.
Punta Tuna Lighthouse, Maunabo, Puerto R.review_summary: This was interesting and a nice bit of history.   This is a no working lighthouse but a pleasant walk with signs explaining the surroundings.   A 30 minute stop.  Our first day in the area, it was closed but later in the week it was open.

Asilo de Pobres Building, Mayagüez, Puer.name: Mayaguez
Asilo de Pobres Building, Mayagüez, Puer.review_summary:
Vinum is a wonderful place to spend a night out in Mayagüez. The ambience is exceptional. The lighting and how everything is laid out makes it very intimate. They have a great selection of wines and hors d'oeuvres for pairing. Likewise, their food is extraordinary. I recommend the truffle-buttered rib eye which was cooked correctly and seasoned appropriately. Next time I will definitely try their various cocktails.

I couldn’t recommend this place more!

Desecheo National Wildlife Refuge, Mayag.name: Desecheo National Wildlife Refuge
Desecheo National Wildlife Refuge, Mayag.description: Desecheo contains a mixture of indigenous, native and exotic species. In the last group are rats, goats, and rhesus monkeys. The latter was presented as part of an unfortunate adaptation experiment ... they adapted so well that they killed all the seabirds that nested there.

Dr. Juan A. Rivero Zoo, Mayagüez, Puerto.name: San Juan
Dr. Juan A. Rivero Zoo, Mayagüez, Puerto.description: The festive city of San Juan is the perfect place to experience true Puerto Rican culture. Get to know its roots by exploring the vibrant neighborhood of El Viejo San Juan (Old San Juan), which consists mostly of Spanish colonial buildings. Flesh out your self-guided history lesson with a visit to El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th century citadel that’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Then reward yourself with a cooling dip at Luquillo or Carolina Beach, then a tasty tour of the Bacardi rum plant.
Dr. Juan A. Rivero Zoo, Mayagüez, Puerto.review_summary: The customer service was top notch!!!! I love how attentive and quickly the staff responded. Provided great communication and helpful.

E. Franco & Co. Bakery, Mayagüez, Puerto.name: E Franco & Co
E. Franco & Co. Bakery, Mayagüez, Puerto.review_summary:
The famous Swiss roll is there - also a good wine selection.  Parking out the front is easy.
There is no fresh Swiss roll - or over the counter - it is all packaged and in boxes.  It was okay.

Mayagüez Resort & Casino, Mayagüez, Puer.name: Mayaguez Resort & Casino
Mayagüez Resort & Casino, Mayagüez, Puer.description: The Mayagüez Resort & Casino is an independently operated, deluxe, full service hotel located in the west coast town of Mayagüez.The hotel is nestled amid 20 acres of scenic, sunny surroundings with spectacular views of the Bay. It is conveniently located 15 minutes from the center of town and the University of PR, Mayagüez Campus; 10 minutes from the Puerto Rico Zoo; 15 minutes from the local Eugenino Maria de Hostos Airport; a 25 minute shuttle flight from the Luis Muñoz Marin San Juan Airport; a 45 minutes drive from the regional Rafael Hernandez Airport in the town of Aguadilla; 25 minutes from the Golf course in Joyuda, Cabo Rojo; and a short ride to the most beautiful beaches and tourist attraction areas.
Mayagüez Resort & Casino, Mayagüez, Puer.review_summary: The Hotel was a Hilton years ago and still have that sense of luxurious from the past. Now have a new tower and new river pool with the old Olympic pool. It's very clean but a little bit outdated in some areas. Also have a new Casino. For me, it's still the best hotel in the west. The staff is very attentive and helpful. The only thing, there's no beach and you have to take a car to get to it. But the west have multiple beaches nearby to choose. The river pool is very nice for all the family.

Parque del Litoral, Mayagüez, Puerto Ric.name: Parque Del Litoral
Parque del Litoral, Mayagüez, Puerto Ric.description: About two miles long, the area's main attractions include Flag Square, Amphitheater, Skateboard Park, and Beach Volleyball and Football areas, among others.
Parque del Litoral, Mayagüez, Puerto Ric.review_summary: Nice place to take amazing pictures of the ocean and the magical sunset scene in the late afternoon. you can walk around, ride  a  bicycle or just take the kids to play around. Also, there is a restaurant where you can have some drinks or eat, nice outdoor bar. Nice ambiance.

location_id.name: Plaza Almirante Cristobal Colon
location_id.description: The Mayaguez main square has a statue of Columbus.
location_id.review_summary: This center of town is credit on a hill. The square is approximately 1/4 mile walk around. It has great statues and a beautiful church in the center. Good restaurants around the center with a small cafe in the square. Great place to visit and shop.

Enrique Laguerre House, Moca, Puerto Ric.name: Puerto Rico
Enrique Laguerre House, Moca, Puerto Ric.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Enrique Laguerre House, Moca, Puerto Ric.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Mundillo Museum, Moca, Puerto Rico.name: Museo del Mundillo
Mundillo Museum, Moca, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Special place - excellent exposition - history involved.  It's a special hand me art performed with love and dedication.

Las Cabachuelas Cave, Morovis, Puerto Ri.description: Las Cabachuelas caverns is a mountainous region located in the Municipality of Morovis. This consists of approximately 60 natural caves.
Las Cabachuelas Cave, Morovis, Puerto Ri.review_summary: Great experience!!! If you love to be in nature consider doing one of the tours from Proyecto Cabachuelas ( fb name). I did the historic caves tour which visits three caves; difficultly level is moderate, the guides are very knowledgeable and friendly. Thanks Miriam and Felix.

Morovis National Cemetery, Morovis, Puer.name: Morovis
Morovis National Cemetery, Morovis, Puer.review_summary: Great place to stop at and get a nice cold beer and something to eat. Their “tostones” are from locally harvested plantains and made to order.

Húcares Waterfront and seafood restauran.name: Naguabo
Húcares Waterfront and seafood restauran.review_summary: We ordered our food to take out (Monday January 27 and 3pm). It was two orders of chillo al ajillo with mofongo and one carucho al ajillo, with mofongo. To begin with the carucho was extremely soft as if it had been stewed, a horrible texture and it had almost no taste and it was thrown on top of the mofongo and when we opened up the order to eat we found an extremely oily and mixed mess. The accompanying salads in both orders had black rot ( lettuce). Oil everywhere maybe they use soybean oil, it's a lot cheaper, who knows. The chillo was a bit better but the mofongo was extremely soft, no taste and oily  The trip was only an eight minute drive back. It was a recommended place but we will not buy (spend money ) there again or recommend it. We love seafood and we know seafood.

La Plata Lake, Naranjito, Puerto Rico.name: Puerto Plata
La Plata Lake, Naranjito, Puerto Rico.description: Well-priced, all-inclusive beach resorts are the norm around Puerto Plata. Take a cable car to the peak of Mount Isabel de Torres, enjoy a concert at an amphitheater facing the Atlantic Ocean, visit the 16th-century San Felipe Fortress. Explore the nearby falls of Damajagua, snorkel off the beautiful island of Cayo Arena or play a round of golf in spectacular surroundings. Then discover the neighboring towns of Cabarete, a kite-boarding hub, and Sosúa, a picturesque beach spot.
La Plata Lake, Naranjito, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Honest review.  This hotel was built 2001 and even though it has been renovated it still shows it's age.  I give it max 3 stars.  This was a family holiday with 2 children 14 & 11.  

**Pros:**
- VIP package and family suite offered perks like VIP check-in, a la carte room service, and some higher-quality liquor at bars.
- VIP family suite is nice and big, but dated.
- Beach and pool were good, though there was limited availability of sunbrellas (they were claimed early in the morning).
- Restaurants were decent, and nightly shows and animation staff were enjoyable.

**Cons:**
- Buffet food was rated poorly (2 stars).
- Only two restaurants open nightly with rotating staff.
- Resort crowd was older, mostly retired individuals.
- Limited activities for kids, making it a dull resort overall.
- Two out of four members of the family got sick (likely from food).
- Resort became very quiet after 10 PM.

Matrullas Lake, Orocovis, Puerto Rico.name: Orocovis
Matrullas Lake, Orocovis, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This was my first visit and the activity I wanted to do to celebrate my birthday. Toro Verde did not disappoint. From start to finish, it was a great time and the staff were equally amazing.

Toro Negro Rain Forest, Orocovis, Puerto.description: TOROVERDE is the ecological park where you will spend endless hours of adventure. You will enjoy the most beautiful landscapes that will leave you breathless, and extreme sports can make direct contact with nature. If you are someone that you like to feel that rush of adrenaline and excitement, this is the place for you.

Peñuelas Pueblo and its main plaza, Peñu.name: Penuelas
Peñuelas Pueblo and its main plaza, Peñu.review_summary: The food here was excellent.  Even though the waiter could not speak English we were able to order lunch. The conch cocktail was fresh and very flavorful.  We had an assortment of dumplings filled with shrimp, trunkfish, octopus and conch.  All were made from fresh ingredients and were delicious.  It’s a little bit off the beaten track but worth it!

Banco de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Ponce
Banco de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

Banco Crédito y Ahorro Ponceño, Ponce, P.name: Ponce
Banco Crédito y Ahorro Ponceño, Ponce, P.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

location_id.name: Isla de Caja de Muertos
location_id.description: Isla de Caja de Muertos is an uninhabited island 8 miles off the coast of Puerto Rico, perfect for a day trip of swimming, relaxing and exploring the Caribbean setting. As part of the Caja de Muertos Nature Reserve, it's home to beautiful reefs, marine life and greenery. Here, you can set off on one of the impressive hiking trails through the undisturbed forest, which leads to an interesting old lighthouse and even a pirates’ cave. You can also book a local boat tour to go snorkeling. This island is a ferry ride away from La Guancha in Ponce.
location_id.review_summary: We went on a private boat, what an amazing island it is. Hopefully, it will open back up soon so people can go. The last time we were there was in May 2022 and they had building material over there to rehab the place, so hopefully it will be open again soon.

El Tuque, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Ponce
El Tuque, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

La Guancha, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: La Guancha
La Guancha, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: La Guancha is one of the hottest hang out spots in Ponce, literally, it's right next to the beach. Take a trip to this boardwalk facing the Caribbean Sea to find an array of fun things to do. Start by having a meal at some of the kiosks turned restaurants, and then have a drink at one of the bars. You can also buy some seeds and feed the birds, fish, and pelicans that are always around the boardwalk grounds. Finish the visit by going up the Guancha Lighthouse and enjoying the view.
La Guancha, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Lovely area of Ponce. Lots of food trucks with a beautiful view. Packed on the weekends. Loved visiting during the week.

Cementerio Católico San Vicente de Paul,.name: Ponce
Cementerio Católico San Vicente de Paul,.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

Panteón Nacional Román Baldorioty de Cas.name: Panteon Nacional Roman Baldorioty de Castro
Panteón Nacional Román Baldorioty de Cas.description: Roman Baldorioty de Castro National Pantheon, also known as Cementerio Antiguo de Ponce, is Ponce's oldest cemetery-turned-museum. With over a hundred years of history since its inauguration in 1842, it was converted into an official pantheon in 1991. This famous burial place is considered Puerto Rico's only National Pantheon, as well as the only cemetery made into a museum in the Caribbean. As the name leads on, the remains of the famous politician Baldorioty de Castro are located here, as well as those of other illustrious people.
Panteón Nacional Román Baldorioty de Cas.review_summary: Roman Baldority de Castro is a Puertorican hero. His tomb and that of the former mayor are in perfect condition however the rest of this old cemetery is overgrown and badly maintained.

Cementerio Civil de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto.name: Ponce
Cementerio Civil de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

Catedral de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe,.name: Catedral de Ponce - Nuestra Senora de Guadalupe
Catedral de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe,.description: This elegant 17th-century cathedral rises majestically in the midst of Ponce.
Catedral de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe,.review_summary:
We visited the Cathedral a couple of times. First we were only able to admire it from the outside. There was no good source of information and we did not realize the 2020 earthquake damage had compromised the building. 
Seeing the Cathedral surrounded by the beautiful square with impressive fountains, trees and historic buildings gives great impression.
By going to the 7AM Sunday Mass we were able to see the Cathedral inside. And indeed one can see some structural damage but the church is alive and well and it is being worked on.

Iglesia de la Santísima Trinidad, Ponce,.name: La Santisima Trinidad
Iglesia de la Santísima Trinidad, Ponce,.review_summary: We had the best experience here. Having visited many wineries throughout the world, this was definitely memorable. Our guide spoke great English, was patient and thorough with explaining every aspect, answering questions and we loved the cheese and fruit pairing with the wines. While this may not be a place a sommelier might appreciate, for the novice or semi-experienced wine drinker it is worth the trip! The wines were balanced and interesting and way better than the average Mexican bottle. The grounds are clean and pretty and the restaurant setting is stunning!

Hotel Melia, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Melia Century Hotel
Hotel Melia, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: Hotel Melia, a historic landmark surrounded by colorful and picturesque monuments, museums and the social night vibes. Located in the heart of downtown Ponce, walking distance to several touristic and cultural attractions such as: Ponce Art Museum, Serralles Castle Museum, Ponce History Museum, the Fire House Museum and many others. Enclosed in the City are numerous culinary and entertaining destinations that are most popular in the Southern Region. Hotel Melia has a total of 70 rooms, a swimming pool, kiddie pool, conference room with capacity for up to 180 persons, Restaurant for breakfast, dinner, tapas and cocktails. We also offer catering, business services, parking, free Wi-Fi. Airport Information: From Hotel Melia to: (PSE) Mercedita International Airport, Ponce- 3 miles (8 min.) (SJU) Luis Munoz Marin International Airport, San Juan- 72 miles (1 hr. 18 Min.) (BQN) Rafael Hernandez International Airport, Aguadilla- 70 miles (1 hr. 27 Min.)
Hotel Melia, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
I love historic hotels so was excited to stay but incredibly disappointed.
Sheet had a stain on it, bathroom was dirty, “balcony” was minuscule (one small chair sideways) and the a/c dripped all over it (totally not worth the extra cost). Also an outside room meant incredibly loud street cleaning and water filling for more than an hour at 4:30am.
This place needs a major cleaning and update of courtyard furniture that is severely stained.
Hope improvements can happen but would discourage anyone from staying as is.

Puerto Rico Iron Works, Ponce, Puerto Ri.name: Puerto Rico
Puerto Rico Iron Works, Ponce, Puerto Ri.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Puerto Rico Iron Works, Ponce, Puerto Ri.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Isla de Gatas, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Isla de Caja de Muertos
Isla de Gatas, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: Isla de Caja de Muertos is an uninhabited island 8 miles off the coast of Puerto Rico, perfect for a day trip of swimming, relaxing and exploring the Caribbean setting. As part of the Caja de Muertos Nature Reserve, it's home to beautiful reefs, marine life and greenery. Here, you can set off on one of the impressive hiking trails through the undisturbed forest, which leads to an interesting old lighthouse and even a pirates’ cave. You can also book a local boat tour to go snorkeling. This island is a ferry ride away from La Guancha in Ponce.
Isla de Gatas, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We went on a private boat, what an amazing island it is. Hopefully, it will open back up soon so people can go. The last time we were there was in May 2022 and they had building material over there to rehab the place, so hopefully it will be open again soon.

Centro Ceremonial Indígena de Tibes, Pon.name: Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center
Centro Ceremonial Indígena de Tibes, Pon.description: Ponce is home to The Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center, an ancient Taino village. It was initially discovered by a charcoal maker from the area, when a large flood in 1975 uncovered the buried remains--which were later shown to be a group of ceremonial plazas and ball fields. Some researchers suggest that, because of their placements, the plazas might have also been used as astral observatories. The largest indigenous cemetery, containing 186 skeletons, was also found. This site is considered to be one of the most important historical and archeological sites in the Antilles.
Centro Ceremonial Indígena de Tibes, Pon.review_summary: Very well run and informative archeological site. Beautiful walk through the outdoor grounds. Besides the ruins there are native trees planted and descriptive signs posted. The museum itself is well laid out with the signage in both English and Spanish. The museum docent is OUTSTANDING! He walked along with us in the museum area and shared lots of knowledge and personal stories about the site and native people. All of this at no cost too!

Hacienda Buena Vista, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Hacienda Buena Vista
Hacienda Buena Vista, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: Come up to the mountains and follow the trail to the waterfall that gave Hacienda Buena Vista its name. What used to be an important coffee plantation was also the scenario of a unique relationship between land, water and slavery. Today, at the heart of the former hacienda is a carefully restored historical site containing structures more than a century old and a hydraulic turbine that's the only one of its kind. Completely refurbished, the turbine is still powered by the water of Río Canas and serves as the main engine for other machines of the time. Spaces are limited, please reserve in advance online or by phone. More dates are available for groups by request.
Hacienda Buena Vista, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: As some other reviews have noted, the opening hours of the Hacienda are erratic. We tried to call for two days to confirm that it was open and the phone was never answered. So next day we drove over. It was closed and the person at the gate said that it was because staff had not shown up for work that day. Too bad it is not better organized because our friends told us it was a great place to visit.

Museo de Arte de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Ri.name: Museo de Arte de Ponce
Museo de Arte de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Ri.description: Its internationally renowned collection comprises more than 5,000 works of art from various cultures, creating a unique dialogue between the Old and New Worlds.
Museo de Arte de Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Ri.review_summary:
I was always aware of the rich collection, especially of European paintings, in the art museum in Ponce.
This was my first chance to see it. 
Visiting the museum, we were not aware of its current condition. No source gave the updates.
The complex apparently suffered in 2020 earthquake and is still undergoing repairs. Only 2 floors are accessible to the visitors but they really give the flavor of the museum collections. 
We were informed that the museum is open on Fridays and on one Saturday a month. We were lucky that it was THAT Saturday. There was no entrance fee. 
The architecturally beautiful building complex seemed at this point intact again, but they may not fully reopen until 2026.
There was an outdoor music concert in front of the museum. The museum gift shop was open. The limited exhibitions were available on the second and third floors.
For me this visit was worthwhile. I am looking forward to revisiting this interesting museum when it fully reopens.
We were able to leave our donation to the museum and buy some beautiful souvenirs in the store.

We were warmly greeted by a friendly employee and also engaged in a nice discussion with another friendly employee on the way out.  It was very warm inside.  Since all of the information was (of course) written in Spanish, we were able to look at different pictures rather than being able to read everything. Parque de la Ceiba, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Parque de la Ceiba
Parque de la Ceiba, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: Ceiba Tree Park is one of the most important markers of history in Puerto Rico. Right in the center is the oldest Ceiba tree, Puerto Rico's national tree. The Ceiba has been gracing old and new generations of poncenos for 500 years. One of the oldest representations of the Ceiba is seen in one of Francisco Oller's paintings from 1888. This ancient tree represents memories, childhood, growth, and good times for many. Generations upon generations of poncenos have dearly cared for this tree, even through the toughest times.
Parque de la Ceiba, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary: La Ceiba Park has one of the oldest trees of the Island, however after the canalization of the river next to the tree, it is dying, with only one branch alive, supported by a metallic structure.The maintenance of the surroundings of the park Is poor.

Centro Cultural de Ponce Carmen Solá de.name: Centro Cultural Carmen Sola de Pereira de Ponce
Centro Cultural de Ponce Carmen Solá de.description: Carmen Sola de Pereira Ponce Cultural Center, founded in November 12, 1963, is the city's cultural center located in its historical zone. Many educational, art, and culture events can be hosted in this antique building. Each month, the center hosts "Noches de Galeria", a night dedicated to art expositions by artists from all over the island, especially Ponce.
Centro Cultural de Ponce Carmen Solá de.review_summary:
Just a block from Parque de Bombas this cultural center exhibits new modern contemporary art of Fulgen Sabarier. 
A new way of colos combinations in an abztract that I feel figurative

Centro de Convenciones de Ponce, Ponce,.review_summary: This was one of our favorites on our trip to Puerto Rico. The service and drinks were great and the grouper was delicious.

Complejo Recreativo y Cultural La Guanch.name: La Guancha
Complejo Recreativo y Cultural La Guanch.description: La Guancha is one of the hottest hang out spots in Ponce, literally, it's right next to the beach. Take a trip to this boardwalk facing the Caribbean Sea to find an array of fun things to do. Start by having a meal at some of the kiosks turned restaurants, and then have a drink at one of the bars. You can also buy some seeds and feed the birds, fish, and pelicans that are always around the boardwalk grounds. Finish the visit by going up the Guancha Lighthouse and enjoying the view.
Complejo Recreativo y Cultural La Guanch.review_summary: Lovely area of Ponce. Lots of food trucks with a beautiful view. Packed on the weekends. Loved visiting during the week.

Cruceta del Vigía, Ponce, Puerto Rico.name: Cruceta Del Vigia
Cruceta del Vigía, Ponce, Puerto Rico.description: Cruceta del Vigia is a 100 feet tall cross located atop Vigia Hill in Ponce, across from Museo Castillo Serralles. It houses a tourist center at its base, a ten-story vertical tower, and a horizontal sky bridge that has panoramic views of the city and the Caribbean Sea. Visitors can reach the skybridge via glass elevators or a staircase. Made of reinforced concrete, the cross has withstood various natural disasters. The arms of the cross measure 70 feet. It was inaugurated in 1984. Owned by the Town of Ponce and is currently operated by the "Patronato de Ponce", a non-profit organization dedicated to preserving and administrating several of the city's landmarks.
Cruceta del Vigía, Ponce, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
As explained in the description, the Vigia Cross (La Cruceta del Vigi­a ) is a 100-foot tall cross-shaped observation tower, located on top of Vigia Hill in Ponce. It is directly behind the Serralles Castle museum.

From its  sky bridge, you have a great panoramic view of the city of Ponce, and the Caribbean Sea. If you’re afraid of heights, you may consider skipping this place. (I felt vertigo walking on the bridge and the access is through a glass elevator). 

I didn’t see any gift shop or restrooms. Tickets are $15.00 and includes the house tour of Serralles Castle and the Japanese garden.

Blanco Historic Bridge, Quebradillas, Pu.name: Quebradillas
Blanco Historic Bridge, Quebradillas, Pu.review_summary:
The views were fabulous and that is the only thing that I can say is positive about this place. The stairs going to the beach were broke, and made no attempt to repair them. Not sure if that was a hot tub or just a pool, but the fiberglass was beyond its life expectancy and was flaking off. We had no service for our room the entire week we were there. Even after we asked the front desk to have our room clean. Unfortunately sand tracked in daily.  The doors were a struggle to get in and out of the room and bathroom, paint was peeling in the room. Room was poorly lit and needed phone light at night to see. Went to restaurant 2x for dinner, and was closed both times.  
After looking at the reviews , the rooms have been an ongoing issue for months.

Guajataca Beach and tunnel, Quebradillas.name: Tunel de Guajataca
Guajataca Beach and tunnel, Quebradillas.description: Built in 1911 for sugarcane trains. The western end of the tunnel connects to the Playa El Pastillo.
Guajataca Beach and tunnel, Quebradillas.review_summary: Absolutely gorgeous! My favorite spot we visited! We were there at sunset but would be a great beach day! Waves are strong so be careful swimming but there is also a natural pool on the beach for children to play in. So much beauty in one spot! Vendors set up during the day and I highly recommend the passion fruit mojitos!  My son and I loved exploring along the beach!

location_id.name: Hotel El Guajataca
location_id.description: Discover the enchanting Hotel El Guajataca in Quebradillas, northwest Puerto Rico, where your stay includes a delightful breakfast. Perfectly positioned by the Atlantic Ocean and a mere 30-minute drive from Rafael Hernandez Airport in Aguadilla, our hotel promises a blend of romantic allure and breathtaking scenery. Relish some of Puerto Rico's finest views from any of our 38 ocean-view rooms, each furnished with TV and air conditioning for your comfort. Adventure seekers can explore the neighboring Guajataca Tunnel and Rio Guajataca, ideal for kayaking, or surf the waves at the nearby Isabela beaches. Immerse yourself in local history and culture with ease. Indulge in exquisite dining at our 19-30 Restaurant & Deck, open for breakfast and dinner seven days a week, enhanced by captivating ocean vistas. We ensure your convenience with free parking and Wi-Fi available in the lobby, rooms, restaurant, and pool area. Our dedicated staff is committed to making your stay unforgettable.

Puerto Hermina Beach and ruins, Quebradi.review_summary: This is a beautiful beach for exploring the caves and the ruins . The waves were pretty high , I wouldn’t recommend this beach for swimming with young children.

Córcega Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.name: Rincon
Córcega Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.description: Rincon is best known for two things—surfing and sunsets. Beaches are small (meaning no huge resort beaches) and no matter how much of a Type-A personality you are, Rincon’s laid-back attitude and leisurely pace will soon win you over.
Córcega Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We had a lovely sailing trip with our instructor, Desmond, and another couple from the US. We learned a lot about basic nautical vocabulary and wind awareness so as to trim our sails. Two hours wonderfully spent. We highly recommend Rincón Sailina.

Domes Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.name: Domes Beach
Domes Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.description: Domes Beach is commonly known by its waves. Located next to the Boiling Nuclear Superheater Reactor Facility and Punta Higuero Lighthouse built in 1892. International surfing competitions take place here.
Domes Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
A great wave beach, but, as others said, watch for rocks and sharpness at the shore.
We took surfing lessons here, and the guide was patient and lovely, but they had had a storm a couple of days prior and the sea was brown/green and cloudy, not blue. He said it was normally quite clear. We also did not have the waves he expected or wanted. For a beginner, that was fine. But you could tell he was a bit disappointed in wave quality. But the main thing is that the rocks on shore were a bit of a challenge to navigate carrying a board into the water. And if we did wipe out close to shore then we got a few scrapes on our feet from the rocks.

Punta Higuero Lighthouse, Rincón, Puerto.name: Rincon
Punta Higuero Lighthouse, Rincón, Puerto.description: Rincon is best known for two things—surfing and sunsets. Beaches are small (meaning no huge resort beaches) and no matter how much of a Type-A personality you are, Rincon’s laid-back attitude and leisurely pace will soon win you over.

Rincón Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.name: Rincon Beach Resort
Rincón Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.description: Nestled on the Bay of Añasco in Puerto Rico's West Coast, Rincon Beach Resort is the perfect escapade for relaxing days under the sun or enjoying an unforgettable dining experience. The West Coast of Puerto Rico, known as Porta del Sol, is home to some of the world's best beaches and surfing areas. Rincon Beach Resort features 112 newly furnished guestrooms with 24 spacious one or two-bedroom condo villas perfect for families, an infinity freeform swimming pool with Jacuzzi overlooking the Caribbean Sea, a swim up bar, lobby bar, Brasas Restaurant and Pelican Beachfront Grill. Rincon Beach Resort offers its guests an array of activities to ensure a memorable experience throughout their stay.
Rincón Beach, Rincón, Puerto Rico.review_summary: First, great bar staff at the swim up bar and housekeeping staff very friendly. However, I have traveled worldwide for work and NEVER arrived at a hotel early to be told that your room is ready but checkin is at 4pm and I can’t give it to you before 2:30pm or it will be an $81 early checkin charge. Also, front desk lady said we could use pool early BUT did not tell us she had towels and had to go back after we got seats! Beautiful beach views!

whale watching viewpoints, Rincón, Puert.name: Rincon
whale watching viewpoints, Rincón, Puert.description: Rincon is best known for two things—surfing and sunsets. Beaches are small (meaning no huge resort beaches) and no matter how much of a Type-A personality you are, Rincon’s laid-back attitude and leisurely pace will soon win you over.

Río Grande Pueblo and its main plaza, Rí.name: Rio Grande
Río Grande Pueblo and its main plaza, Rí.review_summary: Joel and Gabriel from the beach were super helpful and professional! Between these two, and the pina coladas at 5 o’clock bar, our stay was perfect! The beach is clean and the water is great! If you get hungry try the tripleta sandwich at the bar and grill right next to the beach entrance!

Hacienda San Francisco, Sabana Grande, P.name: Hyatt Vacation Club At Hacienda del Mar
Hacienda San Francisco, Sabana Grande, P.description: Situated on a prime stretch of Dorado Beach, Hacienda del Mar epitomizes the beauty and charm of the Island of Enchantment. With its ideal location and well-appointed offerings, Owners and guests can customize their time away. Enjoy on-site amenities, venture into historic San Juan, or immerse yourself in nature at El Yunque National Forest. For tropical relaxation, the family-friendly resort boasts direct beach access, an Olympic-sized and kids’ pool, whirlpool spas, and an array of activities and games. Stop by Mahi Mahi Bar and Grill to refuel after a fun-filled day and participate in our Inspired Experiences program to leave Dorado with unforgettable family memories.
Hacienda San Francisco, Sabana Grande, P.review_summary:
I was pleasantly surprised by the Hyatt Hacienda del Mar in Dorado, Puerto Rico.
My husband and I booked our trip through Expedia and I was reluctant to go to Puerto Rico. I had been to Puerto Rico twice before and the last time, we also stayed in the Dorado area. 

I checked the Hyatt website after we booked our trip and the website said there may be noise at the hotel due to construction. I called the hotel and the representative was honest and said that on one side of the hotel, there is demolition occurring and there may be noise during day hours but it is not every day and not so bad. At this point, it did not matter because our stay was already booked.

The size of the hotel is perfect. It is not huge so that one has to walk a lot and yet it is spacious. The property has beautiful grounds which include a tennis court and basketball court (by the parking lot, across the road from the main entrance). Parking is spacious and FREE which was a big plus for us since we rented a car this trip. The pool at the hotel has 8 laps (a must for my husband who loves to swim) and extends to an additional swimming area and another smaller pool (for babies and kids). There are two hot tubs (one on each side of the pool area). 
There are plenty pool chairs and seating areas. The landscaping is magnificent with palm trees surrounding the pool area. As far as hotel activities, there is bingo and meditation and other activities varying by day. The hotel grounds have a small soccer area and volleyball area and two bbq grills. The clubhouse has a game room for kids with air hockey, a pool table and other games. The gym is well stocked with lots of equipment and is open 24 hours a day (just use your room card).
The pool hours are until 10 pm and the pool is well lit at night.

The beach is private and magnificent. The hotel room we were given was a corner unit with a full kitchen, huge balcony and had views of both the pool and ocean.
The staff was amazing and super helpful and friendly. There is a small bar/restaurant (not formal) that is privately owned - just right for cocktails and drinks and light meals.

I highly recommend the Hyatt Hacienda del Mar. I hope to return soon. The hotel completely changed my views regarding Puerto Rico. It is definitely worth a visit!

location_id.name: Susua State Forest
location_id.review_summary:
I was surprised to see the place so well maintained. Here DRNA makes a great effort to keep it enjoyable. I did not visit the houses this time, only the main visitor's area. A place of peace and nature. Bring your binoculars if you're a bird fan. Not many places in Puerto Rico can take you so deep in a forest.
Be patient and careful on the street in and out. It is very narrow. There is no cell phone signal at all, so bring your two way radios and inform your family you will be out of the radar.
Other than that, visit and enjoy. Please bring all that you need before arriving.

Albergue Olímpico, Salinas, Puerto Rico.name: Albergue Olimpico German Rieckehoff
Albergue Olímpico, Salinas, Puerto Rico.description: The Albergue Olpico German Rieckhoff, named after the founder, is the most complete sport center in all America. It has 45 sport training facilities, including an athletic center, physicial training gimnasium, shooting range, baseball, soccer, and softball fields, tennis courts, an aquatic center, and much more. The Albergue Olímpico also houses a specialized sports school, a sports academy, an olimpic museum, and the famous Olimpia Water Park.
Albergue Olímpico, Salinas, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Water park is small but “ok”. The parks has too many restrictions. 2 adults can’t be at the same time in the children’s area. Can’t wear protective “wet shoes” or rx sunglasses while on rides. Not even big parks like wet n wild, volcano bay and typhoon lagoon have these type of rules. 

Most likely won’t come back anytime soon.

Campamento Santiago, Salinas, Puerto Ric.name: Salinas
Campamento Santiago, Salinas, Puerto Ric.review_summary: Reviews indicated that this was a great spot. We were very disappointed. Food was disappointing. So were drinks. The cost was very high for what we got. Many other restaurants would offer better food and definitely better prices.

Salinas Pueblo and its main plaza, Salin.name: Salinas
Salinas Pueblo and its main plaza, Salin.review_summary: Reviews indicated that this was a great spot. We were very disappointed. Food was disappointing. So were drinks. The cost was very high for what we got. Many other restaurants would offer better food and definitely better prices.

Church of San Germán de Auxerre, San Ger.name: San German
Church of San Germán de Auxerre, San Ger.description: This 400-year-old fortress rises dramatically to greet seaborne visitors to the island.
Church of San Germán de Auxerre, San Ger.review_summary: We had a big truck and it was extremely hard to get around downtown area. Couldn’t find parking and ended up being super frustrated and just left. Buildings looked cool but no real attractions worth it to stop

Interamerican University Historic Campus.name: San Juan
Interamerican University Historic Campus.description: The festive city of San Juan is the perfect place to experience true Puerto Rican culture. Get to know its roots by exploring the vibrant neighborhood of El Viejo San Juan (Old San Juan), which consists mostly of Spanish colonial buildings. Flesh out your self-guided history lesson with a visit to El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th century citadel that’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Then reward yourself with a cooling dip at Luquillo or Carolina Beach, then a tasty tour of the Bacardi rum plant.
Interamerican University Historic Campus.review_summary: The customer service was top notch!!!! I love how attentive and quickly the staff responded. Provided great communication and helpful.

Porta Coeli Church, San Germán, Puerto R.name: El Convento de Santo Domingo de Porta Coeli
Porta Coeli Church, San Germán, Puerto R.description: Built by Dominican monks in 1606, this Gate of Heaven served as a town jail in the 19th century, and is now a small museum displaying carved wooden religious figures.
Porta Coeli Church, San Germán, Puerto R.review_summary:
San German is a beautiful small town in the PR southwest. It reminds on European small towns with old cobbled streets, compact central area and this historic Church.
Porta Coeli dates back to early 17c built by Dominican monks. Today it's a museum, displaying historic artifacts, medieval wood carved Saints, etc..
San German's main Church is some 500 met away, just across the Plaza in front.
Plan around 2 hrs to walk and visit this picturesque and calm small town.

San Germán Historic District, San Germán.name: San German
San Germán Historic District, San Germán.review_summary: Good ambience and excellent Food. We had the eggplants and then the clams … A. Then we had the fish with tomatoes and olives A+ and the pasta with pears A+ . The pizza was Outstanding. Good wines too. Very Good Job.

San Germán Underground, San Germán, Puer.name: San German
San Germán Underground, San Germán, Puer.review_summary: Good ambience and excellent Food. We had the eggplants and then the clams … A. Then we had the fish with tomatoes and olives A+ and the pasta with pears A+ . The pizza was Outstanding. Good wines too. Very Good Job.

Condado Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Condado Beach
Condado Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: Lined with swanky resorts and high-rise hotels, this large beach is a popular spot in San Juan, loved for its vibrant scene, lively dining, and endless array of things to do. While swimming isn't encouraged (powerful rip tides are common here), you can still lounge by the beach and watch surfers, boogie boarders, and parasailers ride the currents. There are also recreational areas like Ventana al Mar where you can take part in an outdoor yoga session or some aqua fitness. Drop by the beach on a city tour of San Juan, which often includes a stop here. – Tripadvisor
Condado Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Fun beach. Waves are fun but be prepared for them and the undertow.  Nothing to be scared of, just expect it. If you aren’t familiar and spent your life in and around it then take it slow.

Ocean Park Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Ocean Park
Ocean Park Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: A serene and charming beachfront neighborhood.
Ocean Park Beach, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We loved this beach. It was so nice. You can bring drinks just not glass. There's a little restaurant but you have to order at least $30 per person so we didn't go there lol. There is a little shop for water/drinks right to the road. It's a short walk from the main road. It's a beautiful beach.

Playita del Condado, San Juan, Puerto Ri.name: Playita del Condado
Playita del Condado, San Juan, Puerto Ri.description: Playita del Condado Beach is an oasis in the heart of Condado. Its hidden just off the east corner of Ashford Ave and Puente Dos Hermanos bridge. A tropical paradise of warm crystalline waters and sparkling golden sands shaded by palm trees and almond trees. This small beach is perfect for kids and family. From the beach, you can enjoy a wonderful view a 500-year-old Fortin (Fort) San Geronimo contrasting with the modernarchitecture of Paseo Caribe at the Plaza Caribe Hilton and the Condado BeachHotel which is only a few blocks away. After lunch you have enough time to drive to Old San Juanand take a walk down the cobbled stone streets of the old city that take you toel Morro fort. A magnificent display of iconic Spanish war architecturebuilt 5 centuries ago and is still standing forever watchful.
Playita del Condado, San Juan, Puerto Ri.review_summary:
I went on a Friday and is just a great little calm-water, very small beach. 

There is no shade, so BYO umbrella is a must. This is actually the beach the used by guests staying at the Conrad, so they will rent lounge chairs, kayaks and umbrellas.

The beach is on the street (Ashford Avenue), so there is a lot of traffic going by. There’s no facilities (no showers, no lifeguards, no bathrooms) and the food stand was closed when I went.   But if you look out to the sea and work around the flaws you can really have a nice time.

Castillo San Cristóbal, San Juan, Puerto.name: Castillo De San Cristobal
Castillo San Cristóbal, San Juan, Puerto.description: This massive, 27-acre historic fort protecting the eastern gate of old San Juan is considered the largest Spanish fort built in the Americas.
Castillo San Cristóbal, San Juan, Puerto.review_summary: Castillo de San Cristobal is a nice stop in Old San Juan if you have enough time. But most visitors are short on time and in my opinion, it would be better to focus on Castillo San Felipe del Morro which is larger and has much better views of the ocean as well. For people into History, there is a lot of information about the history of Puerto Rico. The Wikipedia page speaks of antique gun shooting which would have been fascinating to watch but we were not there on a 3rd sunday

Castillo San Felipe del Morro, San Juan,.name: Castillo San Felipe del Morro
Castillo San Felipe del Morro, San Juan,.description: An esplanade greets you as you walk towards the Fort San Felipe del Morro. Surrounded by grassy hills, the stone castle rises majestically from the headland. And while El Morro may be an impressive sight from land, it is a terrifying experience to encounter it head on by sea. And for many attackers, it was the very last thing they saw. This fortress has seen many battles over the centuries, from Sir Francis Drake's attack in 1595 to the 1898 Bombardment of San Juan by the US Navy. In 1539 King Charles I ordered the construction of San Felipe del Morro and other fortifications on the islet of San Juan. Over the years, Spanish, Italian, Irish and American engineers perfected San Juan's defense system, of which el Morro was an essential part. After crossing the stone bridge over the dry moat, you'll walk right into a spacious courtyard that harbor leads you into the castle's more "domestic" areas, such as the kitchen and the chapel. Nevertheless, this is just one of the six levels that form el Morro. On the upper level, you'll find the lighthouse that was restored by the American Coast Guard in 1908. One of the greatest things about this vantage point is that you can see most of San Juan and the bay across from it. Park rangers will guide you throughout the massive fortification, which still houses original cannons, ammunition, and many other objects used by the Spanish militia in Puerto Rico. El Morro was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1983, and is currently under the administration of the National Park Service.
Castillo San Felipe del Morro, San Juan,.review_summary:
An easy walk from the cruise terminal, follow the coastline path, which takes you through part of the old town, which is spectacular. The fort itself is only $10 to get in (or use your US National Parks card for free) and this also get you in Castillo San Cristobal jus along the coast.

There are plenty of info boards telling you about the long histoty of this important defensive position. The views out-to-sea & inland on all sides of the fort are magnificent.

Walk round the perimiter of the outside edge of the fort to see the igarnos and then decend to sea-level to walk the concrete prominade path. It's abosolutley lovely.

The gift shop is expensive, wait until you get back to the quayside to buy your souvenirs.
