La Fortaleza, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Calle De La Fortaleza
La Fortaleza, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: The vibrant canopy of umbrellas characterizes this unique street of Old San Juan. Here, you can roam the cobblestoned pathways, admire the colonial-era buildings, and do a little bit of shopping for souvenirs and handicrafts. For a little more history, you can join a guided tour of La Fortaleza, the governor’s official mansion that's just around the corner. And don't leave without snapping a picture of the colorful canopy—it changes throughout the year so you can always look forward to something new. The alley can get busy so come early in the morning when it’s quieter. You can visit on a walking or segway tour of Old San Juan, which often makes a stop here. – Tripadvisor
La Fortaleza, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: The umbrellas weren't up in January as the Christmas decorations were still out. We were sad not to find the colorful umbrellas, but the street itself was lovely.  All the beautiful pastel buildings were picturesque.  It was near the pigeon plaza too, so we enjoyed the birds.  We had done research that said Old San Juan was a cab drive from the cruise port, but honestly we (family of five with kids ages 19, 22, and 24) walked through the city from the cruise port seeing different shops, streets, plazas, etc. until we reached the fort on the upper side.  It was not hard to walk and we enjoyed the views along the way, stopping for photos or ducking into shops.  After our walk, we ate lunch at La Verguenza for lunch on the roof and they truly had the best empanadas I've ever had and the drinks and steak churasco were fantastic too - just a short walk from Calle De La Fortaleza.  Made for a nice day!

Capitol of Puerto Rico, San Juan, Puerto.name: The Capitol of Puerto Rico
Capitol of Puerto Rico, San Juan, Puerto.description:
Visitors to the Capitol can make a reservation for a guided tour.
The history of the Capitol building began on February 7, 1907, when Don Luis Munoz Rivera, an important figure of the political history of Puerto Rico and legislator at the time, introduced House Bill 84 to the House of Delegates. Although the bill was passed and a neoclassical design had been chosen, the construction of the Capitol encountered several fiscal, economic and political difficulties which resulted in the work being suspended twice. Despite all difficulties encountered throughout the years, the Capitol building was finally inaugurated on February 11, 1929.
On June 30, 1977, the Capitol of Puerto Rico was designated a Historic Landmark and on November 18, 1977, it was listed on the United States National Register of Historic Places.
Capitol of Puerto Rico, San Juan, Puerto.review_summary: A very grand building is the seat of government for the territory.  Government business takes place here and this building does not look tropical, it looks like it belongs in Washington.  Impressive.

location_id.name: La Placita de Santurce
location_id.description: La Placita de Santurce is one of Puerto Rico’s nightlife hotspots, attracting both locals and travelers. The placita was originally set up as a market square for local produce, and if you visit during the day, you’ll find a number of colorful stalls and restaurants. However, when the sun goes down, out come the live music and partygoers. Head to one of the many bars for cocktails, and even join salsa dancing on the streets. When hungry, be sure to try out one of the placita’s delicious empanadillas. Don't miss all the best spots on a bar hopping tour of San Juan. – Tripadvisor
location_id.review_summary:
It’s really safe and I had no problem.
I had a lot of fun!
You can hear music everywhere and you can also spot people dancing.
I came here from Italy and I had high expectations which have been accomplished when I went there.
It’s definitely a must-go if you go to Puerto Rico!

Miramar, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Casita Miramar
Miramar, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: CASITA MIRAMAR, Authentic Puerto Rican food in an elegant and family style environment. Experience a taste of the Caribbean in a traditional Miramar 'casona' where every space is unique.
Miramar, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Fantastic experience and local food. Make a reservation! Our server Gabriel was very knowledgeable and clearly loves his job. They easily accommodated dietary issues. The complimentary soup was delicious; the octopus and shrimp salad was fresh and tender; our mahi-mahi was locally caught and perfectly cooked. Walk around this former 4-story hotel and see all the nooks and crannies for dining tables.

Old San Juan, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Old San Juan
Old San Juan, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: This historic area in San Juan exudes old-world charm. Walk along the cobbled streets and past colorful buildings, historic fortresses, and old city walls, some of which date back to the 16th century. You might even chance upon local musicians playing some salsa or jazz tunes. There are also several museums where you can learn more about the history, art, and culture of the area, plus cool cocktail bars and restaurants for a quintessentially Puerto Rican meal. Don't miss all the best sights (and food!) on a walking tour of Old San Juan. – Tripadvisor
Old San Juan, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: The real value of a walk through Old San Juan is seeing the cross-section of a variety of ways of life.  You have some Spanish history mixed with almost a New Orleans' style architecture.  This is then mixed with the destruction wrought by multiple hurricanes and the lack of funds to do proper repairs.  Then add the tourist vibe, heavily emphasizing either fast food type chains, t-shirt and jewelry places, and tobacco-type shops.  Not exactly clean streets, but fascinating for people-watching.  Last, and rather sad really, you see some of the poverty that seems common amongst peoples living in warm island climates.  Not unique to the world, but perhaps to a U.S. territory.  For those who want some taste of internationalism but still want to pay for goods in USD, it's a unique place to take a stroll through.

Caribe Hilton Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Ri.name: Caribe Hilton Hotel
Caribe Hilton Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Ri.description: Daily Resort Charge includes: Internet access: fitness center & tennis court access: exclusive beach access with chairs & umbrellas: pina colada tasting: daily recreational amenities & activities: 20% off spa and other discounts: local/toll free calls. This recently restored iconic beachfront resort in San Juan is set on an exclusive peninsula with 17 acres of beach-front tropical gardens, secluded beach, 3 oceanfront pools, full service spa, sun-filled fitness center and several restaurants, including Morton's The Steakhouse and Caribar, home of the Piña Colada. Ideally located at the gateway to historic Old San Juan and just a 15-minute drive from Luis Muñoz Marín Airport, the open-air expansive lobby welcomes you upon arrival with the option for a contactless check-in experience thanks to Hilton's innovative digital check-in and digital key technologies.
Caribe Hilton Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Ri.review_summary:
Second time here .disregard the poor reviews ( hint car door opens for ladies ? )

The staff and rooms are up to par . Central location . Beaches are limited due to rocky shoreline but there is a lagoon . 

Easy walk to the Fort and old San Juan and the same to the hotel Vanderbilt which is a beautiful hotel
at three times the cost of the Hilton . 

Enjoy …..

Condado Vanderbilt Hotel, San Juan, Puer.name: Condado Vanderbilt Hotel
Condado Vanderbilt Hotel, San Juan, Puer.description: Magnificent Spanish Revival architecture, stunningly opulent interiors and dramatic ocean views frame the graceful facade of one of the most storied hotels in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Since its inception in 1919, the Condado Vanderbilt Hotel has catered to sophisticated travelers who place one aspiration above all else - to pursue a lifestyle of five-star luxury and leisure within some of the world's most exclusive destinations. Restored to its original grandeur by virtue of a meticulous renovation, this cherished landmark stands today as a monument to timeless elegance and style. We invite you to discover Puerto Rico as it is meant to be experienced - where exacting service, exquisite amenities and fine dining are a hallmark of every stay. Become part of the Condado Vanderbilt legend during your next escape to San Juan.
Condado Vanderbilt Hotel, San Juan, Puer.review_summary:
The hotel is beautiful. You’re presented with such a beautiful smell on entry. The winding stairs and the ocean view in the distance secures your vacation mode. We were booked to stay Thursday - Sunday. However, that first impression was immediately disrupted by my welcoming. 
1. Thursday - There was quite a wait to check in given that our check in was 4p and it was after 4p. I was greeted with kindness, but did not receive the same welcome to my right and left. I booked the 2 bedroom suite and was told that one of my rooms was available. She mentioned that I would receive a phone call when my other room was available. I gave a card for a $600 incidentals hold. She gave me one wristband (key), and didn’t offer any more (5 ppl were staying in the suite). I asked for one additional key. She then pushed the welcome letter to me stating that this is our welcome letter. I clearly saw the other two guests getting a full layout of the welcome letter with traffic control-like directions to where the amenities were. Also, we were not offered any assistance with our luggage, whereas the other two guest were. The double queen room was nice, and the city view was beautiful. The entry way door looked to have been kicked in, so I made sure to notify the front desk via phone call. We went to OSJ, and I never received a phone call that the room was ready. We stayed out past 9p. When asked when was the room ready, I was told 6:15. The king bedroom was incredible. We had two balconies. One facing the city and one facing the ocean. We were there celebrating my birthday so 2 bottles of champagne were waiting for us, which I believe was courtesy of my travel agent suggesting that it was birthday. The door wasn’t fixed so we slept with both inside doors latched and locked. 
2. Friday - No one came to check on the door last night nor the morning, so I mentioned it to the front desk before we left for the day. Came back late afternoon and spoke to Alejandro about the door and he said he’d have someone take a look. No one came the entire day. 
3. Saturday - Still no fix to the door. Went out early morning and received a text at 1:38, PR time, from Krystal, our supposed butler stating “don’t hesitate to contact me if you need anything.” That was the first I’d heard from her the entire trip. A HUGE disappointment!!!!! I spoke to Alejandro on arrival back to the hotel. He reported that a butler should have been waiting for us at check in, checking in with shift changes, and provided contact information. I received NONE of that until Saturday afternoon. I also reminded him of the door that no one had fixed. Alejandro gave apologies, offered at $400 credit, and said he would send someone up. The service guys came up to fix the door at 7:37p and we were sent bottles of champagne at 7:44p and 7:50p. The guys “fixed” the door but did not fix the latch, which was loose at the top, so I called them back to fix that. I was unaware at the time, but when my sister went to lock the lock on that door when we were going to bed, it wouldn’t even lock!!! 
4. Sunday - I asked for a late check out (12p vs 1p) given that our room wasn’t ready on arrival, and the front desk lady (blanking on her name but I believe it started with a G) approved the request, said she’d have a bell hop gather our luggage 15 minutes before that so it will already be downstairs waiting for us, and suggested we go to Pannes for brunch. Very sweet and accommodating. We put all of our luggage in the doorway. Walked the east wing for the first time and found that there was a rooftop, bigger pool, an infinity pool, and a restaurant on the east wing of the hotel. Granted we could have found it on our own, but this is something I could have been made aware of with a FULL discussion of the welcome letter. Nonetheless, our luggage was still in our room when we came back upstairs for a quick room sweep for any left items. Our driver arrived at 1250 so everyone went to the van, while I checked out. At check out, with Leena, I briefly told her about the many disappointments of our stay, and asked for a copy of the $400 credit to ensure it would be put back on my card. I mentioned that the driver was waiting on me to take us back to the airport. She took at least 3-5 minutes to return. Mind you, two people checked out quickly and were told they’d receive an emailed copy of their receipt. Leena came back and said that the $600 hold was not charged, and the $400 credit was applied. However, I owed $218 worth of tariffs for the stay. I was charged $197, $210, and $210 daily for our stay. Apparently, the tariffs are the hotel taxes and gratuity, which the 20% gratuity was NOT worth it because we didn’t receive the treatment that came with the room. Heavily disappointed, yet again, because this is something that I should have been made aware of at check-in!!!  I did not have enough time to discuss the charge further because our driver was pushing us to leave. 
Again, the hotel is beautiful. The common areas are modernized. The turndown service was great. The staff, at face value, have immaculate customer service, but there’s a lack communication to certain guests of amenities and amongst staff, AND the follow-through is an after thought. We were a group of people of color (POC), from the states, and one of very few groups of POC seen on site the entire stay. The blatant DISCRIMINATION was subtle and loud all in the same breath. We found that discrimination against African Americans was isolated to the Condado area. I expected the red carpet to be rolled out being that we were in a suite with a butler, as advertised on the website, and that it was my birthday celebration. All I expected in return was genuine communication and apology, follow-through, and what we paid for. Yet, that was far from the case. We were given false information, subpar treatment from non-POC counterparts, and bottles of champagne. I did not associate our treatment here with all of San Juan, because we had an incredible time, and encounter genuinely wonderful people elsewhere, so I will revisit the island. Thus, I would NEVER recommend this place to anyone nor stay here again, which would most likely be fine for this company.

Hotel El Convento, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Hotel El Convento
Hotel El Convento, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: Located in the heart of historic Old San Juan, Hotel El Convento has set new standards of luxury, comfort and service while preserving the rich character of this former 16th century convent. This landmark treasure, a member of Historic Hotels of America and Small Luxury Hotels of the World, has earned four diamonds from AAA each year since its opening. This is the exclusive hotel experience to indulge the most discriminating of travelers, and is a hotel like no other.
Hotel El Convento, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: A stay at El Convento situates you conveniently in the heart of old San Juan, surrounding you with the rich history of a people and culture. The service people - front desk, housekeeping staff, concierge services - made obvious  efforts to insure guests' comfort and convenience; from check-in to check out we received timely response to requests. Without a car we had no problem securing transport to anywhere we wanted to go. (It appeared the staff had good relations with taxi services so we never had to wait.) Adisha, Alexander, Juan Carol and Rachel couldn't have been more welcoming. At El Convento you'll enjoy the history of an old convent and the friendliness and convenience  of a modern hotel.

La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort, S.name: La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort
La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort, S.description: Embark on a beach getaway at La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort. Our resort in Condado, Puerto Rico is steps from Condado Beach and provides easy access to Old San Juan and pristine beaches in the popular district of Isla Verde. Upscale amenities include gorgeous beach views, three outdoor pools, six signature dining venues and a 24-hour fitness center.
La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort, S.review_summary: The lobby, beach, food, gym and service was all 5 star.  The room was nice but not as nice as The Royal Sonesta where we stayed after.  The rooms are clean and the view from our room was great - just felt more like a 4 star than 5.  Convient to walk to a ton of restaurants.  Staff was all so kind and helpful with recommendations.

Normandie Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: San Juan
Normandie Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: The festive city of San Juan is the perfect place to experience true Puerto Rican culture. Get to know its roots by exploring the vibrant neighborhood of El Viejo San Juan (Old San Juan), which consists mostly of Spanish colonial buildings. Flesh out your self-guided history lesson with a visit to El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, a 16th century citadel that’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Then reward yourself with a cooling dip at Luquillo or Carolina Beach, then a tasty tour of the Bacardi rum plant.
Normandie Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: The customer service was top notch!!!! I love how attentive and quickly the staff responded. Provided great communication and helpful.

San Juan Marriott Resort & Stellaris Cas.name: San Juan Marriott Resort & Stellaris Casino
San Juan Marriott Resort & Stellaris Cas.description: Only five miles from Luis Munoz International Airport, located in the prestigious Condado neighborhood of San Juan, find the spectacular San Juan Marriott Resort & Stellaris Casino. Our resort in San Juan, Puerto Rico sits in a highly desirable beachfront location only minutes from numerous restaurants and bars. The property boasts 513 spacious guest rooms and 12 suites, most with spectacular Atlantic Ocean views; the 24 hour Stellaris Casino on site, two outdoor pools, two lighted tennis courts and Ocean Club Wellness Center that features a wide array of massages and treatments in addition to the health club. Food & Beverage offerings include La Vista Latin Grill, La Isla Beach Bar & Grill, La Isla Pool Bar, Wan Chai Noodle Bar, Coffee Merchant and the ultra chic Red Coral Lounge. Come and enjoy the comfort and atmosphere of everything this "Caribbean Cosmoplitan Beach Club" has to offer.
San Juan Marriott Resort & Stellaris Cas.review_summary: So it's a mess of so many problems.  Check in was easy.  We got to our 'suite' which started the mess.  Turns out they have a very limited number of 'suites', i.e. a separate bedroom from the tv / entry area, so what they advertise as a suite is just a larger than a standard room.  Also, very few rooms have a direct ocean view, so they consider any slice of a view of the water as an "ocean view".  It's really false advertising.  Within the room, there's minimal overhead lighting.  One side of the bed has no outlets, so it's annoying for two people to charge their phones overnight.  Downstairs, they offer multiple 'restaurants', but each has a very small footprint with highly overpriced bland food, i.e. no brand-name restaurants on property like the other local hotels offer.  So please just walk down the street (or get a ubiquitous uber) for meals.  Grocery stores are nearby as well.  The only exception (and the reason they get two instead of one star) is breakfast.  Really nice spread of options, all included for gold and above level members.  The gym is very strange, as it seems to be open to memberships so it was full of bodybuilders that are intimidating to weekend warrior hotel guests.  The spa is very small, limited rooms with some cleanliness issues, and limited treatment options.  You pay some exorbitant 'resort' fee of $65 per day for internet (you should get for free) and to play tennis for an hour, though no one seemed to be playing.  Towels are locked up because they don't trust you (and I guess $65 per day per room isn't enough to replace lost towels).  Bottom line, not in a 1000 years would I ever think of returning here if it was a stateside hotel.  Even if I was headed back to PR, I'd think of avoiding marriott just to never set foot in this hotel again.

Residencia Luis Muñoz Marín, San Juan, P.name: Parque Luis Munoz Marin
Residencia Luis Muñoz Marín, San Juan, P.description: The renovated Luis Munoz Marin park is a spectacular area to spend a day with family. As you enter, you'll find two areas where kids can play with water. The central area has towers decorated with mosaics. The other area has a large pool that's decorated with mosaics and has water spouts. Amidst the other attractions, there is an elevated route where you can walk among trees and enjoy a view atop the park. One of the favorite areas for older attendees has an enormous spider that is larger than 20 feet of height. There are two areas for pets. There are various areas for children to play football. There is a mini field available for football players. If you enjoy walking through open and natural spaces, the park is surrounded by modern sidewalks and colorful seats. -ZeePuertoRico
Residencia Luis Muñoz Marín, San Juan, P.review_summary: The park is no nice and clean, lots of families enjoying. I went for the doggie areas, which are great, they have two smaller closed areas and one big one with benches big trees and doggie obstacles. There is a park attendant in the entrance of the larger doggie park keeping and eye on the area. Lots of staff working all around the park which is great too. I recommend this park for a nice walk, pets and families.

Casa Blanca, San Juan, Puerto Rico.name: Casa Blanca Museum
Casa Blanca, San Juan, Puerto Rico.description: Built in 1521 as a home for Governor Juan Ponce de Leon, today this historic landmark contains two interesting museums of Indian and colonial artifacts.
Casa Blanca, San Juan, Puerto Rico.review_summary: What a beautiful home and beautiful gardens. The home features a lot of information on the architecture and primarily on the building materials and structure. And while the furnishings are not original to the home, they were clearly historic - it would have been lovely if there had been signage about the furnishings and paintings, etc. The view from the balcony was amazing. If you're lucky, you may get a glimpse of some of the feral cats who roam the area.

Museum of Art of Puerto Rico, San Juan,.name: Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico
Museum of Art of Puerto Rico, San Juan,.description: More than just an art museum, Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico hosts concerts and festivals as well. The Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico (MAPR), a non-for-profit organization, was inaugurated on July 1, 2000, as a legacy for the Puerto Rican people. The mission of the Museo de Arte de Puerto Rico is to enrich the lives of its diverse audiences by making accessible and promoting the knowledge, appreciation, and enjoyment of visual arts from Puerto Rico and the world. The MAPR engages diverse communities to facilitate learning experiences about the visual arts through: the growth of a well-researched permanent collection exemplifying significant and representative examples of Puerto Rican art from the sixteenth century to the present; a dynamic program of exhibitions supported by engaging and exciting educational and cultural programs that collectively deepen the understanding of the role of the visual arts in the human experience and contribute to the creation of a curatorial legacy; documentation, research, interpretation, preservation, and conservation of the collection and the visual arts patrimony of Puerto Rico; and alliances with local, regional, and international museums and institutions to advance the knowledge of, access to, and understanding of the visual arts of the world.
Museum of Art of Puerto Rico, San Juan,.review_summary: A small museum, mostly filled with various types of modern art.  Not at all crowded when we visited on a Saturday morning.

Puerto Rico Convention Center, San Juan,.name: Puerto Rico Convention Center
Puerto Rico Convention Center, San Juan,.description: Puerto Rico Convention Center has everything you need in one spectacular setting. With a sleek, modern design and 600,000 square feet of total space, PRCC is the largest and most technologically advanced meeting facility in the region. It’s also one of the greenest, with a 20,000-panel solar array and numerous other initiatives focused on sustainability. More than just a venue, PRCC is the anchor of a fast-growing Convention Center District, with hotels, restaurants, and more. At the forthcoming District San Juan complex — located just across the street from the convention center — your delegates will be able to sip rum at a micro-distillery, dine at a world-class restaurant, and dance the night away to live music at an outdoor stage, with more than 140,000 additional square feet of meeting space.
Puerto Rico Convention Center, San Juan,.review_summary: A big modern convention center that takes advantage of the balmy climate and the sea location to welcome visitors for meetings and shows.  A good place to attend a meeting, but not part of the typical beach tourist experience.

Luis Muñoz Marín Park, San Juan, Puerto.name: Parque Luis Munoz Marin
Luis Muñoz Marín Park, San Juan, Puerto.description: The renovated Luis Munoz Marin park is a spectacular area to spend a day with family. As you enter, you'll find two areas where kids can play with water. The central area has towers decorated with mosaics. The other area has a large pool that's decorated with mosaics and has water spouts. Amidst the other attractions, there is an elevated route where you can walk among trees and enjoy a view atop the park. One of the favorite areas for older attendees has an enormous spider that is larger than 20 feet of height. There are two areas for pets. There are various areas for children to play football. There is a mini field available for football players. If you enjoy walking through open and natural spaces, the park is surrounded by modern sidewalks and colorful seats. -ZeePuertoRico
Luis Muñoz Marín Park, San Juan, Puerto.review_summary: The park is no nice and clean, lots of families enjoying. I went for the doggie areas, which are great, they have two smaller closed areas and one big one with benches big trees and doggie obstacles. There is a park attendant in the entrance of the larger doggie park keeping and eye on the area. Lots of staff working all around the park which is great too. I recommend this park for a nice walk, pets and families.

Plazuela de la Rogativa, San Juan, Puert.review_summary: I'm only giving 3 stars because this is a nice place, but not a must visit location if you are on limited time. Plaza Las Américas, San Juan, Puerto Ric.description: Plaza las Americas is the largest shopping mall in the Caribbean. It contains more than 300 stores, restaurants, a food court, and a cineplex offering first-run movies in English and Spanish.
Plaza Las Américas, San Juan, Puerto Ric.review_summary: A very modern shopping center, very clean and well-organized.  It has some familiar chain stores, plus some local ones.  Obviously a good place to shop and buy, but not all that interesting for tourists.

location_id.name: DISTRITO T-Mobile
location_id.description: DISTRITO T-Mobile combines the best in art, music, destination dining and technology into an ever-evolving experiential complex in the heart of San Juan. We are Puerto Rico's premier entertainment destination.
location_id.review_summary: Not really my kind of scene but I can understand how this attraction could occupy some hours for preteens and teens. Interesting colorful artwork and places to stroll in shade.

Hiram Bithorn Stadium, San Juan, Puerto.name: Hiram Bithorn Stadium
Hiram Bithorn Stadium, San Juan, Puerto.description: Catch the Caribbean World Series at this baseball stadium.
Hiram Bithorn Stadium, San Juan, Puerto.review_summary: Maybe the most fun I have had at a baseball game in a long time.  From the music to the overall energetic atmosphere, this place is fun!  And baseball!

Old Country Club Stadium, San Juan, Puer.name: Old San Juan
Old Country Club Stadium, San Juan, Puer.description: This historic area in San Juan exudes old-world charm. Walk along the cobbled streets and past colorful buildings, historic fortresses, and old city walls, some of which date back to the 16th century. You might even chance upon local musicians playing some salsa or jazz tunes. There are also several museums where you can learn more about the history, art, and culture of the area, plus cool cocktail bars and restaurants for a quintessentially Puerto Rican meal. Don't miss all the best sights (and food!) on a walking tour of Old San Juan. – Tripadvisor
Old Country Club Stadium, San Juan, Puer.review_summary: The real value of a walk through Old San Juan is seeing the cross-section of a variety of ways of life.  You have some Spanish history mixed with almost a New Orleans' style architecture.  This is then mixed with the destruction wrought by multiple hurricanes and the lack of funds to do proper repairs.  Then add the tourist vibe, heavily emphasizing either fast food type chains, t-shirt and jewelry places, and tobacco-type shops.  Not exactly clean streets, but fascinating for people-watching.  Last, and rather sad really, you see some of the poverty that seems common amongst peoples living in warm island climates.  Not unique to the world, but perhaps to a U.S. territory.  For those who want some taste of internationalism but still want to pay for goods in USD, it's a unique place to take a stroll through.

Here’s a polished version of your restaurant review with improved flow and clarity:

I just had a memorable Sunday lunch at Marisquería Jibara. The rodaballo was cooked to perfection, and the gambas, swordfish, and ahi tuna were equally outstanding—each dish offering something unique. The service by Jimmy and Berto was truly exceptional.

You don’t have to go to San Juan to enjoy a fine dining experience on par with Ariel or El Chotis. The ambiance was further elevated by the gentle strains of classical guitar and the soulful harmonies of the “trios” playing softly in the background.

A remarkable dining experience—highly recommended!

Church of St. Sebastian Martyr, San Seba.name: Donostia - San Sebastian
Church of St. Sebastian Martyr, San Seba.description: While many visitors come for the beaches, arts celebrations and fiestas, San Sebastian-Donostia is serious about its food and drink. The Old Quarter’s narrow, winding streets are full of bars and restaurants, and in the modern city, sidewalk cafes are all around. The city specializes in seafood. Just make sure you know not to expect dinner at 6 or 7 p.m.—that’s much too early in Spain. Instead, tide yourself over with tapas, and enjoy eating and drinking late into the night.
Church of St. Sebastian Martyr, San Seba.review_summary: Our tour bus took us up to the top of this hill, well almost to the top.  We had a modest additional climb uphill, but it was worth it for the splendid views.  There were some attractions for kids and a couple of places for food and drinks.  The view was the main attraction.

Gozalandia Waterfalls, San Sebastián, Pu.name: Catarata Gozalandia
Gozalandia Waterfalls, San Sebastián, Pu.description: Gozalandia waterfalls, also known as Charca de la Leche, are a popular destination for locals and tourists alike. With their milky appearance and lush green surroundings, the waterfalls are a picturesque sight. The natural pools formed by the waterfalls are perfect for taking a dip, swimming with small fishes, and enjoying the summer heat. Kids will love jumping off the boulders and trying out the rope swing, while younger children can safely play in the shallow areas of the pools. Don't forget to check out the small underwater cave too. You can visit the waterfalls on a full-day tour from San Juan. – Tripadvisor
Gozalandia Waterfalls, San Sebastián, Pu.review_summary: Beautiful…quite the drive getting there, but worth it.  There are bathrooms.  No entrance fee, but $10 to park your car.  The parking lot is not huge. I can imagine that on weekends and warmer weather they fill up quickly.

Hacienda El Jibarito, San Sebastián, Pue.name: Hacienda El Jibarito
Hacienda El Jibarito, San Sebastián, Pue.description: Finding an ideal charming bed and breakfast in San Sebastian does not have to be difficult. Welcome to Hacienda El Jibarito, a nice option for travelers like you. Hacienda El Jibarito Hotel offers guests an array of room amenities including air conditioning. The property also features a two pools, a waterfall and a natural enviroments for your recreation. Guests arriving by vehicle have access to free parking. San Sebastian is also home to Museo de la Hamaca, Museo Doña Visa and Museo Hacienda la Fe, all of them are not too far from Hacienda El Jibarito. Hacienda El Jibarito puts the best of San Sebastian at your fingertips, making your stay both relaxing and enjoyable.
Hacienda El Jibarito, San Sebastián, Pue.review_summary:
Nice place super clean great atmosphere and the personality very friendly in the middle of a mountain 
A beautiful waterfall near by. Enjoy the best restaurant in Puerto Rico is located in center of downtown San Sebastián “MARISQUERÍA JIBARA REST. The best seafood in the island

Caguana Indigenous Ceremonial Center, Ut.name: Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center
Caguana Indigenous Ceremonial Center, Ut.description: Ponce is home to The Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center, an ancient Taino village. It was initially discovered by a charcoal maker from the area, when a large flood in 1975 uncovered the buried remains--which were later shown to be a group of ceremonial plazas and ball fields. Some researchers suggest that, because of their placements, the plazas might have also been used as astral observatories. The largest indigenous cemetery, containing 186 skeletons, was also found. This site is considered to be one of the most important historical and archeological sites in the Antilles.
Caguana Indigenous Ceremonial Center, Ut.review_summary: Very well run and informative archeological site. Beautiful walk through the outdoor grounds. Besides the ruins there are native trees planted and descriptive signs posted. The museum itself is well laid out with the signage in both English and Spanish. The museum docent is OUTSTANDING! He walked along with us in the museum area and shared lots of knowledge and personal stories about the site and native people. All of this at no cost too!

Caonillas Lake, Utuado, Puerto Rico.name: Centro Vacacional Lago Caonillas Utuado
Caonillas Lake, Utuado, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Excellent views.  Nice place to share with family and friends.  Or even by yourself.  Plan your visit considering visting the sorroundings and nearby places.  A visit to CAguana Indian Ceremonial Park is a must.

Church San Miguel Arcángel of Utuado, Ut.name: Utuado
Church San Miguel Arcángel of Utuado, Ut.review_summary: Book this hidden gem adventure! The trip is worth the hike. Not too hard, and there is beauty the whole way. BJ was the best guide, we felt safe and informed about plants and wild life along our journey. The nature is breathtaking, the river refreshing and beautiful. The caves were amazing!!!! We look forward to trying another hike on our next trip to P.R.!

Dos Bocas Dam, Utuado, Puerto Rico.name: Lake Dos Bocas
Dos Bocas Dam, Utuado, Puerto Rico.description: Lake Dos Bocas is an artificial lake that was created on 1942 as a hydroelectric power plant and works as a water reserve. The lake features a creative culinary experience. It is located between the towns of Arecibo and Utuado. It also has five restaurants that you are taken to by boat. You can board the boat from a dock called El Embarcadero that departs every hour and makes stops at all of the restaurants. The boat ride takes about 30 minutes where you can enjoy nature, the beautiful lake and think about the delicious food you could indulge.
Dos Bocas Dam, Utuado, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Beautiful and relaxing weekend away from the city and popular tourist areas. Rented a kayak from Hacienda Las Cascadas and stayed in La Finca Regina Airbnb.

Río Abajo State Forest, Utuado, Puerto R.name: Rio Abajo State Forest
Río Abajo State Forest, Utuado, Puerto R.description: Hike through old indigenous forest trails and visit a cave adorned with petroglyphs. Camping grounds are available every day. Groups of more than 9 people require a permit from the Department of Natural Resources.

Utuado Pueblo and its main plaza, Utuado.name: Utuado
Utuado Pueblo and its main plaza, Utuado.review_summary: Book this hidden gem adventure! The trip is worth the hike. Not too hard, and there is beauty the whole way. BJ was the best guide, we felt safe and informed about plants and wild life along our journey. The nature is breathtaking, the river refreshing and beautiful. The caves were amazing!!!! We look forward to trying another hike on our next trip to P.R.!

La Placita Güisín and Lin-Manuel Miranda.name: Galeria Lin-Manuel Miranda
La Placita Güisín and Lin-Manuel Miranda.review_summary: If you are in the area you should stop in.  This is a wonderful tribute about and by Lin-Manuel Miranda.  Staff was knowledgable and enthusiastic about all things LMM.  Website says make appointment.  No need.  Just call or email and tell them when you are comming.

Casa Alonso Museum, Vega Baja, Puerto Ri.name: Vega Baja
Casa Alonso Museum, Vega Baja, Puerto Ri.review_summary: Had 4 meals 2 were chicken and 2 were the Lobster, Shrimp special.  Ironically this is a seafood restaurant and the Seafood was Horribly prepared, while the Chicken was OK.  The Lobster and Shrimp were overcooked,  Lobster was so dried out that the shell was stuck to the meat. Being in PR Mofongo should not be too easy to mess up but somehow they managed to prepare the most awful Mofongo I have had in PR, being watery, gritty with a hint of old oil and old seafood.  My guest also stated how overcooked and dry their lobster was.  The Server did not come ask how things were. When they finally came, while I was conversing with my guests,  they cleared my plate of lobster stuck to the shell and the mofongo,  When we talked to management,  they would not help or offer any thing to make up for the horrible service and food since the server had cleared my plate.

Black Sand Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.name: Black Sand Beach
Black Sand Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Beautiful beach. TVieques. We ended up taking the ferry to this island and rented a to the beach is very muddy and slippery. Also there was a lot of horse manure along the path. We took the ferry to the island and rented a golf cart to get around.

Caracas Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.name: Playa Caracas
Caracas Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Pure paradise! The water and view were spectacular. Not too crowded at all. We went in the afternoon and it was absolutely perfect.

Conde de Mirasol Fort, Vieques, Puerto R.name: Isla de Vieques
Conde de Mirasol Fort, Vieques, Puerto R.description: The glowing Mosquito Bay is a vision of bizarre beauty. Thanks to a bioluminescent microorganism, the water is a cool electric blue, looking somewhat like a fantastical sci-fi lagoon. Kayak or hop into a clear-bottomed pontoon boat to glide along the neon waters. Swimmers and snorkelers will adore the pristine, undeveloped beaches. Keep an eye out for the playful feral horses that gallop along the dunes, or visit the stately ceiba tree that’s been keeping watch over the highland for three centuries.
Conde de Mirasol Fort, Vieques, Puerto R.review_summary: We had a wonderful snorkel with Crystal Clear. Randy was a fantastic guide who took our lead in terms of pace and interests. He was super knowledgeable and was especially great with our teenagers. He really tapped into their curiosities and made it so enjoyable for all of us. We saw a multitude of fish species, numerous turtles and even a small octopus. Highly recommend!

La Esperanza Beach, Manatí, Puerto Rico.name: Hacienda La Esperanza
La Esperanza Beach, Manatí, Puerto Rico.description: Follow the historical trajectory of Hacienda La Esperanza Nature Reserve in Manati, one of Puerto Rico’s most prosperous sugar plantations during the 19th Century, where the main driving force behind sugar production was slavery. During this tour, you will visit the different structures that make up La Esperanza’s Historical Site, including the Sugar Mill and its unique 1861 West Point Foundry steam engine. Spaces are limited, please reserve in advance online or by phone. Facilities for the handicapped are limited because of uneven terrain.
La Esperanza Beach, Manatí, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Llegamos a la Hacienda La Esperanza alrededor de las 10:30 a.m. (según su sitio web, abren de 8 a.m. a 4 p.m.) este pasado Martes 12 de Febrero y fuimos recibidos por un guardia, quien nos informó que no podían dejarnos entrar ya que no había suficiente personal. Inmediatamente sugirió que regresáramos otro día. Le expliqué que manejamos un poco más de dos horas para llegar allí y que era extremadamente decepcionante que debido a problemas de personal no nos permitieran entrar luego de haber echo tan largo viaje. Pregunté: ¿habrá suficiente personal en el futuro? y su respuesta fue “no podía estar seguro de eso”.
Estábamos muy entusiasmados con poder visitar la antigua hacienda y su falta de personal/consideración nos arruinó el día. Espero que en un futuro sean más consientes y mantengan sus instalaciones con personal adecuado para poder atender a todo visitante. También les sugiero que si están teniendo dificultades para poder atender el público lo informen en su página web y/o redes sociales para que así todo aquel que esté considerado visitarles tenga esto en mente. De lo contrario les sugiero que no habrán sus puertas.

English translation.

We arrived at Hacienda La Esperanza around 10:30 a.m. (according to their website, they are open from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.) this past Tuesday, February 12, and we were greeted by a guard, who informed us that they could not let us in since there were not enough staff. He immediately suggested we come back another day. I explained that we drove a bit over two hours to get there and that it was extremely disappointing that due to staffing issues we were not allowed in after such a long trip. I asked: will there be enough staff in the future? and his response was “I couldn't be sure of that.”
We were very excited to visit the old hacienda and their lack of staff/consideration ruined our day. I hope that in the future they will be considerate and maintain their facilities with adequate staff in order to be able to serve all visitors. I also suggest that if they are having staffing issues, they inform them on their website and/or social media so that everyone who is considering visiting them has this in mind. Otherwise they shouldn’t bother opening their doors.

Isabel II Town and its main plaza, Viequ.name: Vieques Island
Isabel II Town and its main plaza, Viequ.description: Isla de Vieques, one of the offshore island municipalities of Puerto Rico, is located just 7 miles off the east coast. Vieques is one of the last destinations that truly remains like the Caribbean of the past: quiet, lush, uncrowded, with unmatched natural beauty. Vieques is home to Mosquito Bay, the brightest bioluminescent bay in the world, and with dozens of undeveloped beach coves, one can experience the true meaning of tropical bliss. This small Puerto Rican treasure is also home to the largest natural wildlife refuge in the Caribbean.
Isabel II Town and its main plaza, Viequ.review_summary:
The views are amazing!! This is more of a getaway, secluded romantic vacation.  If you’re looking to party and the beach and what not then this is not the island to go to.  Also, since it’s an island plan to travel almost half the day to the resort!! there’s only I believe two or three taxis on the island. It takes 30 minutes to get to one side of the island and the other. But when you land at the airport, it’s an hour taxi or Uber ride to the ferry, which where you have to wait with a bunch of people who actually live there! They speak a lot of Spanish so I would suggest learning some Spanish…. Especially when you take the 30 minute ferry ride to the island then people really only speak Spanish. You run into a few Americans obviously. However, that is their language!! it’s a beautiful island. The resort I stayed at, had wild horses just walking around, an infinity pool, the horses were not mean at all. I literally have videos of me petting one, although I suggest to be careful. 
It’s about a 15 minute walk to the black sand beach. Again, I’m speaking of the resort I stayed at. And we each had our own little bungalow. I would’ve gave this hotel 10 stars or the island 10 stars but everything closes early around 3 to 4 PM and I’m talking like grocery stores. There’s not many there. They’re more like little gas stations. But they have the necessities water milk you know stuff like that. There was a few bars that were open late Ish. The normal hours to midnight or two … also like any trip make sure you book any events ahead of time! :-) as they were completely out of every single thing to do on my birthday!!! They wouldn’t even do anything so that was pretty upsetting. And that was the entire island I called.

La Chiva Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.name: Playa La Chiva
La Chiva Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.description: Vieques National Wildlife Refuge and all visitor facilities is closed due to impacts from Hurricane Irma. Refuge closures include all hiking trails, boat ramps, fishing access, and other recreational use on refuge lands. The closure remains in effect until the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service assesses storm damage and has determined it is safe for visitor access.
La Chiva Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.review_summary: Amazing beach. We saw 4 starfish, a turtle, some small and some big old fish. Spent the day in the shade and snorkeling. Bring bug spray! Beautiful!

Sun Bay Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.name: Balneario Sun Bay
Sun Bay Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.description: If paradise had palm trees...they'd call it Sun Bay.
Sun Bay Beach, Vieques, Puerto Rico.review_summary: What a beautiful beach! I don’t know if it’s where we set up, but we barely saw anyone and the waves and weather were picture perfect. Highly recommend for a quiet beach day in Vieques.

Vieques Bioluminiscent Bay, Vieques, Pue.name: Bioluminescent Mosquito Bay
Vieques Bioluminiscent Bay, Vieques, Pue.description: Watch the world’s brightest bioluminescent bay glow as you paddle a glass-bottomed kayak. Catch a ferry at the port outside the town of Ceiba to reach the quiet island of Vieques off the east coast of Puerto Rico. Vieques’ secluded mangrove bay is beautiful during the day but simply astonishing after sunset. You’ll marvel at the neon blue trail left by microorganisms whenever they are disturbed—just dip your hands in the water and watch the effects. Visit on a dark night (e.g. during a new moon) to ensure peak visibility of the phenomenon.
Vieques Bioluminiscent Bay, Vieques, Pue.review_summary: Biobay tour with Jake and Ryan. Beautiful evening with a half moon. We learned so much about the dinoflagellates from Ryan, who is truly passionate about the science and teaching others!! The water sparkled even with the moonlight. It was a perfect experience!

Vieques National Wildlife Refuge, Vieque.name: Vieques National Wildlife Refuge
Vieques National Wildlife Refuge, Vieque.description: Much of the land on this new wildlife reserve was once a naval bombing range.
Vieques National Wildlife Refuge, Vieque.review_summary: This is a most amazing place. If you are looking for comfy beach chairs and all the creature comforts of a vacation resort, this is not it. If you want to experience the land, the beach, the sea...just as it IS...this is the place. We took our rental Jeep back the windy road and spread our towels under the coconut trees and enjoyed a beach without another human in sight or hearing. Just us and Mother Nature. It is a top ten highlight of my life, truly. Just the most natural and peaceful setting.

Cerro Maravilla, Villalba, Puerto Rico.name: Puerto Rico
Cerro Maravilla, Villalba, Puerto Rico.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
Cerro Maravilla, Villalba, Puerto Rico.review_summary:
Staff super!

The rooms are sparsely furnished with no drawers, storage space, or designated toiletry areas. While it might be okay for a weekend getaway, it’s not comfortable for extended stays, as we found ourselves rummaging through our suitcases.

The fire alarm goes off frequently due to people smoking in a non-smoking area. It typically goes off after 11 p.m.

The pictures don’t accurately represent the size of the rooms and bathrooms. Everything is smaller than you’d expect.

Swimming in the ocean is not recommended at this resort because it’s rocky and has a strong undertow. There is a beach area where you can relax if you’d like.

One thing we truly enjoyed was the incredible bed and sheets.

If you rent a car, be prepared to pay $30 per day for In-N-Out privileges and there’s a valet service.

Additionally, there’s a $65 daily tourist tax that we were surprised to encounter when checking out.

The food at their restaurants was generally good.

Dead Dog Beach, Yabucoa, Puerto Rico.name: Yabucoa
Dead Dog Beach, Yabucoa, Puerto Rico.review_summary: We have been there several times and it has always been great until yesterday… the service was HORRIBLE. When we arrived we ordered 2 soups and some wings (both were very good). The waitress went to ask what we wanted for the main dish. When we finished the soups, we asked about the wings and she told us they were about to come out. After a loooong wait, when she only brought my main dish, I told her to forget about the wings, that we were going to wait for my husband’s main dish. Long story short: They served the table next to us before us, I finished my dish, and after about 10-15 minutes the waitress brought the wings, even though I had told her to cancel them, she didn’t listen to us. About 10 minutes later my husband’s dish arrived. The service was a DISASTER… it’s a shame that such a nice place, with young and enterprising owners, falls apart due to poor service to their customers.

El Cocal Beach, Yabucoa, Puerto Rico.name: Playa El Cocal
El Cocal Beach, Yabucoa, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This is a great public beach. The road is well marked.  The beach has a small parking lot. The water in February was a little rough. Very important - stay away from the rocks to the right of the entrance, stay close to the middle.  The ocean floor in the middle is more sandy. And if you have a little children, there is a natural shallow pool area at the far end.

Césari Mansion, Yauco, Puerto Rico.name: Yauco
Césari Mansion, Yauco, Puerto Rico.review_summary: You must visit! Second time and we will be back. Loved the ravioli app and our server offered the option for vegetable risotto which was out of this world! The brownie dessert with Ice cream was one of the best brownies I have ever had! Coffee and drinks were excellent as well. Tostones were cooked beautifully. And the servers were attentive and very warm and friendly. Best food for the price around!

Pico Rodadero, Yauco, Puerto Rico.review_summary: This is definitely one of the most beautiful peaks in Puerto Rico. With a great view and a well-maintained trail to the top, is a hike for almost everyone.

If you rent a car, be prepared to pay $30 per day for In-N-Out privileges and there’s a valet service.

Additionally, there’s a $65 daily tourist tax that we were surprised to encounter when checking out.

The food at their restaurants was generally good.

National Register of Historic Places lis.name: Puerto Rico
National Register of Historic Places lis.description: Puerto Rico offers the perfect balance of rum-soaked nightlife and tranquil retreat. The Spanish colonial buildings of San Juan set a perfect backdrop for a day of shopping and sightseeing. Hike the massive El Yunque rainforest to see waterfalls, stone towers, and colorful Puerto Rican wildlife. As far as beaches go, it doesn’t get better than the private sands of Isla de Vieques – particularly Mosquito Bay, where by moonlight the water glows blue-green thanks to magical microorganisms.
National Register of Historic Places lis.review_summary:
Staff super!

The rooms are sparsely furnished with no drawers, storage space, or designated toiletry areas. While it might be okay for a weekend getaway, it’s not comfortable for extended stays, as we found ourselves rummaging through our suitcases.

The fire alarm goes off frequently due to people smoking in a non-smoking area. It typically goes off after 11 p.m.

The pictures don’t accurately represent the size of the rooms and bathrooms. Everything is smaller than you’d expect.

Swimming in the ocean is not recommended at this resort because it’s rocky and has a strong undertow. There is a beach area where you can relax if you’d like.

One thing we truly enjoyed was the incredible bed and sheets.

If you rent a car, be prepared to pay $30 per day for In-N-Out privileges and there’s a valet service.

Additionally, there’s a $65 daily tourist tax that we were surprised to encounter when checking out.

The food at their restaurants was generally good.
